ocular tuberculosis, a rare but serious infection caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis that can affect virtually any ocular tissue, often mimicking other eye conditions and potentially leading to vision loss.

disease: Cushing disease due to pituitary adenoma
description: Cushing disease due to pituitary adenoma, an endocrine disorder in which a benign pituitary tumor produces excessive ACTH that leads to increased cortisol secretion and a range of systemic symptoms.
lamellar ichthyosis, a rare genetic skin disorder present at birth that disrupts normal skin shedding and results in thick, scaly layers of skin.

disease: sleep disorder, initiating and maintaining sleep
description: sleep disorder, initiating and maintaining sleep, a condition characterized by difficulty falling asleep or staying asleep that leads to daytime impairment and reduced quality of life.
Graves disease, an autoimmune disorder that causes overproduction of thyroid hormones leading to hyperthyroidism and potentially affecting the eyes, skin, and other organs.
myeloproliferative neoplasm, a group of rare chronic blood cancers characterized by the abnormal and uncontrolled production of blood cells in the bone marrow.
typhus, a group of infectious diseases caused by rickettsia bacteria transmitted through lice, fleas, or mites and marked by fever, headache, and rash.
ecthyma, a deep bacterial skin infection that causes painful ulcers beneath crusted sores.
multiple endocrine neoplasia, a group of rare inherited disorders that cause tumors and abnormal activity in multiple endocrine glands.
malignant epithelial tumor of ovary, a common invasive carcinoma arising from the ovarian surface cells that frequently metastasizes and whose prognosis depends critically on early detection.

hereditary isolated aplastic anemia, a rare genetic disorder characterized by constitutional bone marrow hypoplasia and severe peripheral blood pancytopenia in multiple family members without somatic symptoms, often presenting with abnormal bleeding and erythrocyte macrocytosis.

vaginitis (disease), is an inflammation or infection of the vagina that typically causes symptoms such as abnormal discharge, itching, and pain, and can result from bacterial imbalances, hormonal changes, or irritant exposure.
nicotine dependence, a chronic, relapsing disease characterized by compulsive tobacco use, withdrawal symptoms, and persistent cravings despite its harmful consequences.
dermatitis, a common inflammatory skin condition that causes redness, swelling, itching, and sometimes rash or blistering, with various forms including atopic, contact, and seborrheic dermatitis.

head and neck cancer, a group of malignancies that develop in areas such as the mouth, throat, nose, sinuses, and salivary glands, often linked to risk factors like tobacco use, alcohol consumption, and human papillomavirus infection.

temporomandibular joint disorder, a condition that affects the jaw joint and surrounding muscles, leading to pain, discomfort, and limited jaw movement often accompanied by clicking sounds and headaches.

hemopericardium (disease), is a condition characterized by the accumulation of blood within the pericardial sac, most commonly due to trauma, aortic dissection, ruptured aneurysms, or underlying inflammatory and malignant diseases, which can lead to cardiac tamponade.

disease: primary cutaneous peripheral T-cell lymphoma not otherwise specified
description: primary cutaneous peripheral T-cell lymphoma not otherwise specified, a rare, aggressive skin lymphoma characterized by non-specific plaque-like lesions and diagnosed by excluding other well-defined T-cell lymphomas.
familial dilated cardiomyopathy, a genetic heart disorder characterized by the thinning and enlargement of the ventricles that impairs the heart's ability to pump blood efficiently.
cholecystitis, an inflammation of the gallbladder typically caused by gallstones blocking the cystic duct, which can lead to severe pain and complications if not treated promptly.
distal myopathy, a group of rare genetic disorders that progressively weaken and waste the muscles in the hands, arms, feet, and legs.

end stage renal failure, is the final stage of chronic kidney disease in which the kidneys can no longer effectively filter waste and excess fluids, typically necessitating dialysis or a transplant to sustain life.
congenital stationary night blindness, is a rare inherited retinal disorder characterized by non-progressive impairment of night vision due to dysfunction in photoreceptor signal transmission.

disease: distal myopathy with posterior leg and anterior hand involvement
description: distal myopathy with posterior leg and anterior hand involvement, is a neuromuscular disorder (also known as distal ABD-filaminopathy) characterized by progressive symmetric muscle weakness and atrophy of the anterior upper limbs and posterior lower limbs, typically inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern with onset in adulthood.
unclassified acute myeloid leukemia, a subtype of AML that lacks definitive genetic or morphological classification and presents with heterogeneous features and rapid disease progression.

dementia (disease), is a neurodegenerative syndrome characterized by a decline in memory, thinking, and behavior that interferes with daily activities, typically arising from various underlying conditions such as Alzheimer’s disease, vascular dementia, and Lewy body dementia.

spotted fever, a tick-borne disease caused by Rickettsia bacteria that typically presents with fever, headache, and rash and can rapidly progress to severe illness without prompt antibiotic treatment.

heart valve disease, a condition in which one or more of the heart's valves malfunction, impairing blood flow and potentially causing symptoms like chest pain, shortness of breath, fatigue, and an increased risk of heart failure or stroke.
dry eye syndrome, a condition characterized by insufficient or poor-quality tear production that leads to eye discomfort, irritation, and blurred vision.
primary biliary cholangitis, a chronic autoimmune liver disease that progressively damages the small bile ducts and can lead to cirrhosis and liver failure.

female stress incontinence, a condition characterized by involuntary urine leakage during activities that increase abdominal pressure due to weakened pelvic floor muscles and urethral sphincter, often resulting from childbirth-related tissue or nerve damage.

Kimura disease, a rare chronic inflammatory disorder of unknown etiology characterized by painless subcutaneous masses, lymphadenopathy, and elevated eosinophils and IgE levels, primarily affecting the head and neck region of young Asian men.

carcinoid crisis, a life-threatening complication of carcinoid syndrome caused by the abrupt release of vasoactive substances from neuroendocrine tumors that results in severe flushing, hypotension, and bronchospasm.

disease: obsolete diabetes insipidus, neurohypophyseal type, X-linked inheritance
description: obsolete diabetes insipidus, neurohypophyseal type, X-linked inheritance, a rare genetic disorder in which X-linked mutations impair the neurohypophyseal secretion of antidiuretic hormone, leading to early-onset polyuria and polydipsia predominantly in males.

obsolete heart block, a condition in which the electrical signals between the atria and ventricles are disrupted, leading to irregular or missed heartbeats that may require pacemaker therapy to prevent serious complications.

Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia, a rare type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma also known as lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma, is a cancer of B cells that produce excessive abnormal IgM protein, leading to varied hematologic and systemic symptoms.

brain injury, a condition typically caused by external force such as a blow or jolt to the head that disrupts normal brain function and can result in a range of physical, cognitive, and behavioral impairments.

giardiasis, a parasitic infection of the small intestine caused by Giardia duodenalis that spreads through contaminated water, food, or person-to-person contact and is characterized by diarrhea, stomach cramps, and nausea.
psoriasis, is a chronic autoimmune disease that causes the rapid buildup of skin cells, leading to red, inflamed, and scaly patches.
periarthritis, a condition caused by calcium crystal deposition around joints and tendons that results in pain, swelling, and stiffness.
polycythemia, a condition characterized by an abnormally high concentration of red blood cells that increases blood thickness and the risk of clot formation.

cerebrotendinous xanthomatosis, a rare autosomal recessive genetic disorder of bile acid and lipid metabolism that leads to abnormal cholestanol accumulation affecting the nervous system, eyes, and tendons.
mucous membrane pemphigoid, a rare autoimmune disorder that causes chronic blistering and scarring of mucous membranes, primarily affecting the mouth and eyes.

disease: autosomal recessive severe congenital neutropenia due to CXCR2 deficiency
description: autosomal recessive severe congenital neutropenia due to CXCR2 deficiency, is a rare primary immunodeficiency disorder caused by recessively inherited CXCR2 mutations that lead to severe neutropenia and recurrent bacterial infections, typically manifesting in infancy.

bejel, a chronic nonvenereal bacterial infection caused by Treponema pallidum subsp. endemicum, is characterized by skin, mucosal, and bone lesions and primarily affects children in unsanitary, endemic regions.

disease: male infertility with spermatogenesis disorder due to single gene mutation
description: male infertility with spermatogenesis disorder due to single gene mutation, a rare genetic condition characterized by defective sperm production and abnormal sperm morphology (such as azoospermia, oligozoospermia, or teratozoospermia) caused by a mutation in a single, critical gene involved in spermatogenesis.
familial dermatographia, a hereditary condition in which even light scratching induces transient raised red wheals, swelling, and itching that typically resolve within 30 minutes.

B-cell neoplasm, a cancer arising from abnormal B lymphocytes that can present as various non-Hodgkin lymphoma subtypes with symptoms like enlarged lymph nodes, fatigue, and night sweats, and is managed with targeted therapies and chemotherapy.

disease: dermatophytosis of groin and perianal area
description: dermatophytosis of groin and perianal area, a superficial fungal infection caused by dermatophytes that produces itchy, red, and scaly rashes in the groin, perineum, and perianal regions.

spondyloarthropathy, susceptibility to, is a genetically heterogeneous condition linked to specific loci on chromosomes 9q31-q34 and 2q36, as well as the HLA-B27 phenotype, which predisposes individuals to a spectrum of inflammatory joint disorders primarily affecting the spine and peripheral joints.

binge eating disorder, is a psychological condition characterized by recurrent episodes of consuming unusually large amounts of food in a short period, accompanied by a sense of loss of control and significant emotional and physical distress.

otitis media (disease), a group of inflammatory conditions of the middle ear—most often following viral or bacterial respiratory infections—that cause symptoms such as ear pain, fluid buildup, fever, and potential hearing difficulties, particularly in children.

osteomalacia (disease), a metabolic bone disorder marked by impaired mineralization due to deficiencies in vitamin D, calcium, or phosphate that results in weakened, softened bones and a heightened risk of fractures.

non-infectious meningitis, is an inflammation of the membranes surrounding the brain and spinal cord caused by non-infectious factors such as autoimmune disorders, medication reactions, head injuries, or cancers, and is managed by treating the underlying condition.
agoraphobia, an anxiety disorder characterized by an intense fear of situations where escape may be difficult or help unavailable, often resulting in avoidance behaviors and panic-related symptoms.

esophageal candidiasis, a fungal infection of the esophagus primarily caused by Candida species that predominantly affects immunocompromised patients and presents with symptoms such as difficulty and pain when swallowing.

eye disease, any condition affecting the eye or its surrounding structures—ranging from cataracts and glaucoma to macular degeneration and diabetic retinopathy—that can impair vision and is best managed through timely diagnosis and treatment.
filarial elephantiasis, a parasitic disease transmitted by mosquito bites that damages the lymphatic system and causes severe swelling and disfigurement of the limbs and other body parts.

sexual and gender identity disorders, a group of conditions encompassing sexual dysfunctions, gender incongruence (including what was once termed gender identity disorder), and atypical sexual behaviors that can cause significant distress and impairment.

aortic valve disease, a condition that impairs the heart’s aortic valve function—either by narrowing (stenosis) or leaking (regurgitation)—thereby disrupting normal blood flow from the heart to the aorta.

septicemic plague, a severe bloodstream infection caused by Yersinia pestis that rapidly leads to systemic toxicity, disseminated intravascular coagulation, and tissue necrosis, proving almost invariably fatal without prompt treatment.

liver cancer, a malignant disease characterized by uncontrolled cell growth in the liver that is diagnosed using imaging, blood tests, and biopsy, with treatment options including surgery, transplantation, radiation, and targeted drug therapies.

obsolete pityriasis, an outdated term formerly used to describe a scaling, papular skin condition often associated with drug‐induced reactions and now replaced by more precise dermatological classifications.
diabetic neuropathy, a nerve damage condition caused by persistently high blood sugar levels in people with diabetes that often leads to pain, numbness, and weakness.
liposarcoma, a rare cancer that originates in fat cells and presents as a type of soft tissue sarcoma with several distinct subtypes that vary in clinical presentation and treatment options.
mite infestation, a condition in which parasitic mites invade the skin, causing intense itching, irritation, and potential allergic reactions.
endomyocardial fibrosis, a tropical disease characterized by the deposition of fibrous tissue in the endocardium that leads to restrictive cardiomyopathy and significant heart failure.

cryopyrin-associated periodic syndrome, a rare, autosomal dominant group of autoinflammatory disorders caused by NLRP3 gene mutations that lead to excessive interleukin‑1β production and recurrent multisystem inflammation affecting the skin, joints, eyes, and central nervous system.

disease: familial adrenal hypoplasia with absent pituitary luteinizing hormone
description: familial adrenal hypoplasia with absent pituitary luteinizing hormone, a rare endocrine disorder characterized by miniature adult-type congenital adrenal hypoplasia with a small amount of well-organized permanent adrenal cortex and selective absence of pituitary luteinizing hormone in an otherwise normal brain, leading to neonatal demise.

fallopian tube cancer, a rare gynecologic malignancy that originates in the fallopian tubes and is often associated with ovarian cancer, typically managed through specialized diagnostic imaging and surgical treatment.

sporadic porphyria cutanea tarda, is an acquired form of porphyria characterized by decreased hepatic uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase activity that leads to the accumulation of porphyrins and results in skin photosensitivity and blistering.

myopathy, a disease of the skeletal muscles characterized by impaired function and weakness due to intrinsic muscle fiber abnormalities from genetic, toxic, endocrine, or critical illness-related causes.
meningeal tuberculosis, a severe form of bacterial meningitis caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis spreading from the lungs to infect the protective membranes of the brain and spinal cord.

calciphylaxis, a rare and serious disorder characterized by calcium deposits in small blood vessels that lead to painful skin lesions, tissue necrosis, and potentially life-threatening complications, most commonly in patients with kidney disease.
Plasmodium falciparum malaria, a mosquito-borne protozoan infection, is the most lethal form of malaria, rapidly progressing to severe illness and accounting for over 90% of global malaria mortality.

calcium metabolic disease, a disorder characterized by disrupted calcium homeostasis due to imbalances in regulatory mechanisms like parathyroid hormone and vitamin D, leading to abnormal serum calcium levels and associated skeletal, neuromuscular, and metabolic complications.

myocardial disorder, a condition affecting the heart muscle characterized by structural or functional abnormalities—such as reduced blood flow, inflammation, or genetic defects—that compromise its ability to pump blood effectively.
open-angle glaucoma, a chronic and progressive optic neuropathy that causes irreversible damage to the optic nerve and gradual loss of peripheral vision due to impaired aqueous humor drainage.

glutaryl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency, an autosomal recessive neurometabolic disorder caused by the deficiency of a mitochondrial enzyme responsible for breaking down lysine, hydroxylysine, and tryptophan, which leads to the accumulation of toxic organic acids and potentially severe neurological damage.
hyperlipoproteinemia, a condition characterized by abnormally high levels of lipids in the blood that increases the risk of heart disease and stroke.
malaria, a mosquito-borne infectious disease caused by Plasmodium parasites that results in fever, chills, and potentially severe complications.
glucose-galactose malabsorption, a rare genetic disorder that impairs the intestinal absorption of glucose and galactose, leading to severe, life-threatening diarrhea and dehydration in infancy.
orthostatic hypotension, a condition characterized by a sudden drop in blood pressure upon standing that can lead to dizziness, fainting, and increased fall risk.

disease: pituitary deficiency due to Rathke's pouch cysts
description: pituitary deficiency due to Rathke's pouch cysts, a rare acquired condition resulting from a benign fluid-filled cyst in the pituitary gland that causes headaches, visual disturbances, and hormonal imbalances.
coronary thrombosis, a life-threatening condition in which a blood clot forms inside a heart artery, restricting blood flow and potentially leading to a heart attack.
erythema multiforme, an immune-mediated skin reaction characterized by red, target-shaped lesions primarily triggered by infections, medications, or autoimmune responses.

intravascular large B-cell lymphoma, a rare and aggressive subtype of non-Hodgkin lymphoma, is characterized by the proliferation of malignant B cells within the lumina of small and medium-sized blood vessels, often presenting with diverse and nonspecific clinical symptoms.

developmental and epileptic encephalopathy, a group of rare and severe epilepsies characterized by frequent seizures and epileptiform activity that contribute to developmental delay, slowing, or regression, typically presenting in early childhood.

esophageal cancer, a rare and aggressive cancer that begins in the lining of the esophagus and is often associated with symptoms such as difficulty swallowing and weight loss, with risk factors including alcohol and tobacco use.

intermediate coronary syndrome, an acute coronary event characterized by atypical, intermediate-duration chest pain and subtle findings that neither meet the full criteria for classic angina nor myocardial infarction.

multiple organ dysfunction syndrome, is a life-threatening condition in which two or more organ systems rapidly fail to function properly due to a dysregulated inflammatory response triggered by severe illness, injury, or infection.

congenital isolated hyperinsulinism, a rare genetic disorder characterized by unregulated insulin secretion from pancreatic beta-cells that leads to severe and persistent hypoglycemia in newborns and infants.

latent yaws, a stage of yaws infection in which individuals exhibit reactive serological tests without clinical symptoms, potentially remaining asymptomatic yet capable of reactivating and spreading the disease.
polycythemia (disease), a rare blood disorder marked by the excessive production of red blood cells that thickens the blood and may lead to serious complications if not properly managed.
tinea pedis, a common contagious fungal infection of the feet that typically causes an itchy, scaly, and sometimes blistered rash, often between the toes.

cholangitis, an inflammation of the bile ducts that can be acute or chronic, is often caused by bacterial infections associated with bile duct obstructions and may lead to symptoms such as fever, jaundice, and abdominal pain.

chronic duodenal ileus, a rare condition also known as Wilkie or SMA syndrome, is characterized by the compression of the third portion of the duodenum between the superior mesenteric artery and the aorta, leading to impaired intestinal transit.
Duchenne muscular dystrophy, a severe X-linked genetic disorder primarily affecting boys due to mutations in the dystrophin gene, causes progressive muscle weakness and degeneration.

Sjogren syndrome, a chronic autoimmune disorder that primarily targets moisture-producing glands, leading to persistent dryness in the eyes, mouth, and other areas while potentially affecting various organ systems.

disease: limb-girdle muscular dystrophy due to POMK deficiency
description: limb-girdle muscular dystrophy due to POMK deficiency, a genetic disorder presenting in infancy with muscle weakness, delayed motor development (often walking by 18 months), and progressive proximal weakness with calf pseudohypertrophy, mild facial weakness, and borderline intelligence.

biliary tract disease, a spectrum of disorders affecting the bile ducts, gallbladder, and related organs that disrupt the flow and function of bile, potentially leading to inflammation, obstruction, and progressive liver damage.

blastomycosis, a fungal infection caused by inhaling spores of Blastomyces dermatitidis that primarily affects the lungs and can disseminate to other organs such as the skin, bones, and central nervous system.
hyperinsulinemic hypoglycemia, a condition caused by unregulated insulin secretion from pancreatic β-cells that leads to abnormally low blood glucose levels.

gastroparesis (disease), is a disorder characterized by delayed gastric emptying due to impaired stomach muscle contractions, often linked to diabetes-induced nerve damage or other underlying conditions.
iritis (disease), an inflammation of the iris that causes eye pain, redness, blurred vision, and sensitivity to light, often linked to autoimmune or infectious conditions.
hyperthyroidism, a condition in which the thyroid gland produces excessive thyroid hormones that accelerate metabolism and can impact various body systems.

post-traumatic stress disorder, a mental health condition that develops after experiencing or witnessing a traumatic event and is characterized by symptoms that impair cognition, mood, and daily functioning.

esophageal disease, a category encompassing various disorders of the esophagus—including inflammation, motility problems, and structural abnormalities such as GERD and eosinophilic esophagitis—that impair the passage of food and may lead to complications like scarring or cancer.

obsolete functional visual loss, a nonorganic visual impairment characterized by self-reported deficits that lack corresponding clinical findings and are attributed to subconscious or psychogenic factors.
rickets (disease), a childhood bone disorder primarily caused by vitamin D deficiency that results in soft, weak bones and skeletal deformities.

distal myopathy, Welander type, is an autosomal dominant, adult-onset muscular dystrophy characterized by slowly progressive weakness of the distal limb muscles, particularly in the hands and lower legs, with a higher prevalence in the Baltic region.

Niemann-Pick disease, a group of rare inherited metabolic disorders caused by enzyme deficiencies that disrupt lipid metabolism and lead to harmful lipid accumulation in various organs such as the brain, liver, and spleen.
intestinal perforation, a life-threatening condition marked by a hole in the intestinal wall that allows contents to leak into the abdominal cavity and requires urgent medical intervention.

intervertebral disc degenerative disorder, a condition characterized by the progressive dehydration and degradation of spinal discs that leads to reduced disc height and chronic pain in the back, neck, or limbs.
plasma cell myeloma, a cancer of plasma cells in the bone marrow that produces abnormal antibodies and leads to bone, kidney, and blood complications.
anxiety disorder, a group of mental health conditions characterized by persistent and excessive fear or worry that interferes with daily life and can produce both psychological and physical symptoms.

aplastic anemia, a rare but serious blood disorder in which the bone marrow is unable to produce enough red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets, leading to potentially life-threatening complications.
collagenous colitis, a chronic inflammatory bowel disease and subtype of microscopic colitis characterized by watery, non-bloody diarrhea and abdominal pain.

acute myeloblastic leukemia without maturation, is a rapidly progressive acute myeloid leukemia subtype characterized by more than 90% undifferentiated myeloid blasts in the bone marrow without significant maturation, leading to ineffective hematopoiesis and symptoms such as anemia, thrombocytopenia, and organomegaly.

acute papillary necrosis, a severe form of renal papillary necrosis, is characterized by rapid ischemic injury and coagulative necrosis of the renal papillae that can lead to sloughing, urinary tract obstruction, and potentially fatal complications such as septicemia and renal failure.
relapsing fever, a bacterial infection transmitted by lice or ticks that causes recurring episodes of fever along with symptoms such as chills, headache, and sometimes rash.

ocular albinism (disease), a genetic condition that primarily affects the eyes by reducing ocular pigmentation and causing vision abnormalities while leaving skin and hair pigmentation largely normal.
ovarian adenocarcinoma, a common epithelial ovarian cancer that predominantly affects older women and is often diagnosed at an advanced stage due to its vague, non-specific symptoms.

familial lipoprotein lipase deficiency, is a rare genetic disorder caused by mutations in the LPL gene that prevent the normal breakdown of dietary fats, leading to severe hypertriglyceridemia, chylomicronemia, and associated symptoms such as abdominal pain, pancreatitis, and eruptive xanthomata typically manifesting in childhood.
hemangioma, a common benign vascular tumor typically seen as a red birthmark or bump in infancy that often regresses on its own but can sometimes require treatment.

hereditary geniospasm, a rare genetic movement disorder characterized by recurrent, stress-related involuntary tremors of the chin and lower lip that typically begin in childhood and tend to improve with age.

hemorrhagic fever-renal syndrome, an acute zoonotic illness caused by hantaviruses transmitted via aerosolized rodent excreta that presents with a spectrum of symptoms from fever and increased vascular permeability to acute kidney injury and hemorrhagic manifestations.
endometritis, inflammation of the uterine lining typically caused by infection following childbirth, abortion, or pelvic procedures.
chronic kidney disease, a progressive condition in which the kidneys gradually lose their ability to filter blood and remove waste, potentially leading to kidney failure.

hypertensive disorder, a condition characterized by persistently elevated blood pressure that can silently damage vital organs like the heart, kidneys, and brain, potentially leading to serious complications such as heart attack, stroke, and organ failure.
testicular seminoma, a type of testicular germ cell tumor that typically grows slowly and is highly curable with treatments such as surgery, radiation, and chemotherapy.

Alzheimer disease without neurofibrillary tangles, a genetically influenced variant of Alzheimer's, is marked by the presence of amyloid plaques and distinct neuronal alterations despite the absence of the typical tau protein aggregates forming neurofibrillary tangles.

sporotrichosis, a fungal infection caused by Sporothrix species typically acquired through skin injuries from contaminated plants or animals that results in skin lesions and may occasionally progress to affect deeper tissues.

Becker muscular dystrophy, an X-linked recessive disorder caused by mutations in the dystrophin gene, leads to slowly progressive muscle weakness in skeletal and cardiac muscles, primarily affecting males.

metabolic syndrome X, a cluster of metabolic risk factors—including insulin resistance, abdominal obesity, hypertension, and dyslipidemia—that collectively increase the risk of heart disease, type 2 diabetes, and stroke.

hyperemesis gravidarum (disease), a severe pregnancy complication characterized by intense nausea and vomiting that can lead to dehydration, weight loss, and malnutrition, potentially posing risks to both the mother and her baby.
hepatitis, a liver inflammation that can be acute or chronic and is most commonly caused by viral infections, though toxins, alcohol use, and autoimmune disorders can also trigger it.
panuveitis (disease), an inflammatory condition affecting all layers of the uvea as well as other ocular structures, which can lead to significant vision loss if not promptly managed.

von Willebrand disease (hereditary or acquired), is a bleeding disorder caused by a deficiency or dysfunction of the von Willebrand factor—most commonly inherited, though an acquired form can arise from other medical conditions—that interferes with normal blood clotting.
ankylosing spondylitis, is a chronic inflammatory arthritis that primarily affects the spine and sacroiliac joints, causing pain, stiffness, and potential vertebral fusion.

atrioventricular dissociation (disease), a cardiac conduction disorder in which the atria and ventricles beat independently due to disrupted impulse transmission through the AV node, leading to arrhythmias that can be asymptomatic or cause symptoms like bradycardia, tachycardia, and loss of coordinated atrial contraction.
cutaneous tuberculosis, a rare extrapulmonary infection caused mainly by Mycobacterium tuberculosis that manifests with diverse skin lesions and is managed with standard systemic anti-TB treatment.
panophthalmitis, a rapidly progressing, severe infection of all ocular structures and the orbit that can lead to blindness if not promptly treated.
agranulocytosis, a life-threatening disorder characterized by an dangerously low number of neutrophils, significantly increasing the risk of severe infections.

adult-onset citrullinemia type I, is a rare autosomal recessive urea cycle disorder characterized by variable hyperammonemia and neurological symptoms in adulthood—including headaches, scotomas, migraine-like episodes, ataxia, slurred speech, lethargy, and drowsiness—with potential for serious increased intracranial pressure.

insomnia (disease), a common sleep disorder characterized by difficulty falling or staying asleep that can lead to impaired daytime functioning and is often associated with various chronic health conditions.

serum sickness, an immune complex-mediated hypersensitivity reaction to foreign proteins in medications, antiserum, or blood products that typically causes fever, rash, joint pain, and other systemic symptoms.

oculopharyngodistal myopathy, a rare hereditary muscle disease typically presenting in adolescence or adulthood and characterized by progressive weakness of the eyelids, facial, pharyngeal, and distal limb muscles accompanied by symptoms like ptosis, dysphagia, and dysarthria with distinctive pathological features such as rimmed vacuoles and intranuclear inclusions.

ascorbic acid deficiency, a condition caused by inadequate vitamin C intake that impairs collagen production and tissue repair, potentially leading to scurvy and other connective tissue abnormalities.

constitutional neutropenia, a benign, often congenital condition characterized by persistently low neutrophil counts in otherwise healthy individuals, particularly common among certain ethnic groups such as those of Mediterranean and African descent.
priapism, a condition characterized by a prolonged and often painful erection unrelated to sexual stimulation that can lead to tissue damage if not treated promptly.
endemic goiter, a thyroid enlargement predominantly caused by iodine deficiency and environmental goitrogens in regions with low iodine levels in soil, water, and food.

familial or sporadic hemiplegic migraine, a rare migraine subtype characterized by temporary motor weakness and other neurological aura symptoms that may be inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern or occur sporadically without a family history.
neonatal jaundice, a condition in newborns characterized by yellow discoloration of the skin and eyes due to elevated bilirubin levels in the blood.
hemoglobinopathy, a group of inherited disorders affecting the structure or production of hemoglobin in red blood cells.
tinea infection, a fungal skin disease caused by dermatophytes that results in red, itchy, and scaly ring-shaped lesions.
thyrotoxicosis, a condition characterized by abnormally high levels of thyroid hormones in the body that result in a hypermetabolic state commonly due to hyperthyroidism or thyroid inflammation.
creeping myiasis, a rare cutaneous parasitic infection caused by fly larvae that migrate within the skin, forming serpentine, erythematous tunnels accompanied by intense itching.
osteoporosis, a disease that weakens and thins the bones, increasing their susceptibility to fractures.

aleukemic mast cell leukemia, a rare and aggressive subtype of systemic mastocytosis marked by an absence of mast cells in the peripheral blood despite their significant accumulation (≥20% atypical cells) in the bone marrow.

varicella zoster infection, a contagious disease caused by a neurotropic double-stranded DNA herpesvirus that initially produces chickenpox and may later reactivate as shingles with characteristic painful or itchy rashes.
elephantiasis, a tropical parasitic disease caused by filarial worms transmitted through mosquitoes that leads to chronic lymphatic obstruction and severe swelling of the limbs and other body parts.

milker's nodule, is an occupational zoonotic skin infection caused by a double-stranded DNA Parapoxvirus from cattle that produces localized lesions which are typically self-limited but can sometimes trigger secondary reactions.

congenital mitral valve insufficiency, is a congenital defect in which the mitral valve fails to close properly during heart contraction, allowing blood to leak backward from the left ventricle into the left atrium.

obsolete hyperuricemia (disease), formerly viewed as a singular cause of gout due to elevated serum uric acid levels, it is now recognized as an outdated concept that fails to capture the condition's broader associations with metabolic, renal, and cardiovascular disorders.

palmoplantar keratoderma, a group of disorders characterized by excessive thickening and scaling of the palms and soles that can be inherited or acquired and may be associated with other systemic features.

polymyalgia rheumatica, is an inflammatory disorder that causes muscle pain and stiffness, particularly in the shoulders, neck, and hips of individuals over 50, and may be associated with giant cell arteritis.

ventricular fibrillation (disease), an abnormal and life-threatening arrhythmia in which the heart's ventricles quiver instead of contracting effectively, leading to compromised blood flow and a significant risk of sudden cardiac death if not urgently treated.
substance abuse/dependence, is a chronic brain disease that impairs control over drug use despite its harmful effects and is treatable through various therapeutic and medical interventions.

acquired angioedema, a rare disorder characterized by recurrent, bradykinin-mediated swelling due to an acquired deficiency or dysfunction of C1 inhibitor, often associated with autoimmune or lymphoproliferative conditions.
lymphoma, a cancer of the lymphatic system that occurs when lymphocytes grow out of control.

biotinidase deficiency, a rare autosomal recessive metabolic disorder that impairs the recycling of biotin, leading to multisystem complications that can be effectively treated with biotin supplementation.
Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, a rare and invariably fatal neurodegenerative disorder caused by abnormal prion proteins that rapidly leads to severe dementia, memory loss, and motor dysfunction.

endocrine pancreas disease, refers to disorders that disrupt the hormone-secreting islet cells of the pancreas, leading to imbalances in insulin and glucagon production and potentially causing conditions such as diabetes mellitus and pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors.
brain glioblastoma, is an aggressive, rapidly growing malignant brain tumor that originates from astrocytes, invades surrounding tissue, and is characterized by a poor prognosis.

Balo concentric sclerosis, a rare and aggressive CNS inflammatory demyelinating disease considered a variant of multiple sclerosis, is characterized by distinctive concentric rings of alternating demyelination and preserved myelin visible on MRI.

iron metabolism disease, a condition characterized by imbalances in iron homeostasis where either excessive accumulation or insufficient levels of iron—due to genetic, nutritional, or pathological causes—lead to various systemic and organ-specific complications.

Laron syndrome, a rare genetic disorder caused by mutations in the growth hormone receptor gene that leads to growth hormone insensitivity, resulting in short stature and various metabolic abnormalities.

anogenital human papillomavirus infection, is a common sexually transmitted viral infection that often remains asymptomatic but can cause benign warts and, in persistent cases, progress to precancers and cancers in the anogenital region and oropharynx.
partial motor epilepsy, a focal seizure disorder characterized by localized involuntary motor activity due to abnormal electrical discharges in a specific region of the brain.

eosinophilic esophagitis, a chronic immune-mediated condition that causes an abnormal buildup of eosinophils in the esophagus leading to inflammation, narrowing, and symptoms such as heartburn and difficulty swallowing.
autosomal dominant coarctation of aorta, is an inherited congenital disorder characterized by a narrowing of the aorta with variable severity and often associated with other cardiovascular anomalies.

ovarian endometrioid adenocarcinoma, a malignant epithelial ovarian tumor that microscopically resembles endometrial adenocarcinoma, often arises in the context of endometriosis and constitutes about 10–25% of primary ovarian cancers.

persistent fetal circulation syndrome, also known as persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn, is a neonatal disorder characterized by the failure of the circulatory system to transition from the fetal pattern, resulting in persistently high pulmonary vascular resistance and associated hypoxemia.

spinal cord disease, a condition where various factors such as trauma, tumors, infections, inflammation, and degenerative or autoimmune disorders disrupt the spinal cord's ability to transmit signals between the brain and the body.
Clostridium difficile colitis, a bacterial infection often triggered by antibiotic use that causes diarrhea, abdominal pain, and inflammation of the colon.
hypogonadism, a condition in which the gonads produce insufficient sex hormones, often resulting in impaired sexual development, reduced fertility, and other health complications.

disease: migraine with or without aura, susceptibility to
description: migraine with or without aura, susceptibility to, is a genetically complex neurological disorder characterized by recurrent headache episodes that may occur with or without sensory aura and are influenced by multiple genetic and environmental factors.

primary motor cortex epilepsy, a form of drug-resistant epilepsy originating from the precentral gyrus that produces focal motor seizures—often evolving through a Jacksonian march—and typically requires precise cortical mapping or resection for effective treatment.
argininosuccinic aciduria, a rare genetic disorder affecting the urea cycle due to argininosuccinate lyase deficiency, which leads to ammonia accumulation that can damage the brain and other tissues.
oculopharyngeal muscular dystrophy, a rare genetic disorder characterized by progressive weakness in the eyelid and throat muscles that causes drooping eyelids and difficulty swallowing.
balanoposthitis, an inflammation of the foreskin and glans of the penis commonly caused by infections, irritation, or trauma, especially in uncircumcised males.
common wart, a benign skin growth caused by human papillomavirus that typically appears as a small, rough bump with tiny black dots on the fingers or hands.
Creutzfeldt Jacob disease, a rapidly progressive and invariably fatal neurodegenerative disorder caused by prions that leads to severe cognitive decline, motor dysfunction, and behavioral changes.

disease: intestinal obstruction in the newborn due to guanylate cyclase 2C deficiency
description: intestinal obstruction in the newborn due to guanylate cyclase 2C deficiency, is an extremely rare autosomal recessive gastroenterological disorder characterized by meconium ileus without the pulmonary or pancreatic features typically seen in cystic fibrosis.

bacterial vaginosis, a common vaginal infection caused by an imbalance of natural bacteria that often results in discharge and odor while increasing the risk of sexually transmitted infections and pregnancy complications.
breast carcinoma, a common cancer that originates in breast tissue, typically from the ducts or lobules, and can spread to other parts of the body.

disease: pituitary hormone defiency from vascular origin
description: pituitary hormone defiency from vascular origin, is a condition in which impaired blood supply to the pituitary gland leads to a deficiency in one or more of its hormones, often seen in cases such as Sheehan syndrome.
gingival overgrowth, an excessive growth of gum tissue around the teeth that can result from inflammation, medications, or systemic conditions.

Yersinia enterocolitica infectious disease, a bacterial zoonosis that primarily causes gastrointestinal illness with symptoms such as diarrhea, abdominal pain, and fever, is most commonly acquired through ingestion of contaminated undercooked pork and other food sources.
breast fibrocystic disease, a common benign condition characterized by lumpy, often tender breast tissue resulting from normal hormonal fluctuations.

obsolete vitamin D deficiency, a historically prevalent condition marked by insufficient vitamin D leading to disrupted calcium homeostasis, rickets in children, and osteomalacia in adults, now largely rare in developed countries.

disease: muscular dystrophy-dystroglycanopathy (congenital with brain and eye anomalies), type a
description: muscular dystrophy-dystroglycanopathy (congenital with brain and eye anomalies), type a, is a genetically heterogeneous autosomal recessive disorder characterized by congenital muscular dystrophy with early muscle weakness, brain and eye malformations, profound intellectual disability, and a shortened life expectancy usually resulting in death during early childhood.
vasculitis, is an autoimmune disorder characterized by inflammation of blood vessels that disrupts blood flow and can lead to tissue and organ damage.

hypertriglyceridemia (disease), is a condition characterized by abnormally high blood triglyceride levels that increase the risk of cardiovascular disease and pancreatitis, typically managed through lifestyle modifications and pharmacotherapy.
calcinosis, a condition characterized by the abnormal deposition of calcium salts in the skin and subcutaneous tissues caused by various underlying factors.

progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy, a rare and often fatal brain disease caused by JC virus infection in immunocompromised individuals that results in progressive demyelination and severe neurological impairment.

recurrent corneal erosion, a painful condition characterized by the recurring detachment of the corneal epithelium due to abnormal adhesion—often following trauma or corneal disease—that results in episodes of sharp pain, light sensitivity, and blurred vision.
gout, an inflammatory arthritis caused by uric acid crystals depositing in joints, which leads to sudden episodes of severe pain and swelling.

sleep apnea syndrome, a potentially serious sleep disorder characterized by repeated interruptions in breathing during sleep that can lead to excessive daytime sleepiness and increased risk of cardiovascular complications.
autosomal recessive Emery-Dreifuss muscular dystrophy, is a rare genetic condition characterized by early joint contractures, progressive skeletal muscle weakness, and cardiac involvement.

human African trypanosomiasis, a vector-borne parasitic disease transmitted by tsetse flies in sub-Saharan Africa, presents in both chronic and acute forms and can cause severe neurological complications if left untreated.

viral meningitis, an inflammation of the membranes around the brain and spinal cord caused by viruses that is typically mild and self-limiting, generally resolving within 7 to 10 days though sometimes requiring supportive treatment in more severe cases.
rat-bite fever, a rare bacterial infection transmitted through rat bites or contact with rodent secretions that can cause fever, rash, joint pain, and potentially severe complications.

soft tissue sarcoma, a rare malignant cancer that develops in the body's supportive tissues—such as muscle, fat, blood vessels, and nerves—and often manifests as a slowly growing, sometimes painless mass that can occur anywhere in the body.

lysinuric protein intolerance, a rare autosomal recessive metabolic disorder caused by mutations in the SLC7A7 gene that impair cationic amino acid transport, leading to protein malabsorption and a range of gastrointestinal, growth, and systemic complications.

pyridoxine deficiency anemia, a condition characterized by low vitamin B6 levels that impair hemoglobin production leading to microcytic anemia, is effectively treated with dietary modifications or vitamin B6 supplementation.

ophthalmic herpes zoster, a reactivation of the varicella zoster virus affecting the ophthalmic branch of the trigeminal nerve, is characterized by a painful, unilateral dermatomal rash that can lead to severe ocular complications such as inflammation, scarring, and vision loss.

lymphangioma, a benign congenital malformation of the lymphatic system that forms fluid-filled cysts or spongy masses often seen in infants and children and typically managed with effective treatment when necessary.

fetal erythroblastosis, a severe alloimmune disorder occurring when maternal antibodies cross the placenta and destroy fetal red blood cells due to blood group incompatibility, potentially leading to anemia, jaundice, and other life-threatening complications.

pyloric stenosis (disease), a condition most often seen in infants where abnormal thickening of the pyloric muscle narrows the stomach's outlet to the small intestine, causing projectile vomiting and potential dehydration that is typically treated with surgery.

hereditary hypophosphatemic rickets, is a genetically mediated disorder characterized by renal phosphate wasting that leads to chronic low phosphate levels and impaired bone mineralization resulting in rickets from early childhood.
parkinsonian disorder, a condition characterized by tremor, rigidity, slowed movement, and postural instability resulting from disrupted dopamine function in the nervous system.

brain stem infarction, a type of stroke caused by an interruption of blood flow to the brainstem resulting in tissue death that can impair vital functions such as consciousness, breathing, and blood pressure regulation.

vitamin K deficiency hemorrhagic disease, is a bleeding disorder in newborns caused by low vitamin K levels that can lead to severe internal hemorrhages, including potentially life-threatening brain bleeds.

familial ovarian cancer, is an inherited condition marked by genetic mutations that significantly increase a woman’s lifetime risk of developing ovarian cancer, often presenting at an earlier age than sporadic cases.

disease: pituitary deficiency due to empty sella turcica syndrome
description: pituitary deficiency due to empty sella turcica syndrome, a condition in which cerebrospinal fluid herniates into the sella turcica, displacing and flattening the pituitary gland and leading to hormonal imbalances such as reduced growth hormone and hyperprolactinemia.
neuralgia, a condition characterized by sharp, intense nerve pain resulting from damage or irritation along a nerve’s pathway.
amyloidosis (disease), a rare condition characterized by the buildup of misfolded amyloid proteins in various organs, leading to impaired function and a range of symptoms.

embryoma, a tumor derived from embryonic (fetal) tissue that may be benign or malignant and typically manifests in infancy or early childhood, encompassing variants such as neuroblastomas and Wilms tumors.
focal hand dystonia, a neurological movement disorder that causes involuntary muscle contractions and abnormal postures in the hand during specific, often repetitive, activities.
adrenogenital syndrome, a group of inherited disorders that impair hormone production in the adrenal glands and gonads, leading to imbalances in cortisol, aldosterone, and sex steroids.

Pick disease, a rare form of frontotemporal dementia that primarily affects the frontal and temporal lobes, is characterized by progressive changes in behavior, personality, and language typically beginning in middle age.
malignant pleural mesothelioma, is a rare and aggressive cancer of the lung lining primarily caused by asbestos exposure and characterized by a long latency period and limited treatment options.

nervous system disorder, a condition affecting the brain, spinal cord, and nerves that can stem from genetic mutations, vascular issues, infections, structural abnormalities, or degenerative processes and includes diseases such as Alzheimer's, epilepsy, and multiple sclerosis.

ligneous conjunctivitis, a rare inherited disorder characterized by chronic inflammation and fibrin-rich, woody pseudomembranes on the conjunctiva and other mucous membranes due to plasminogen deficiency.

composite hemangioendothelioma, is a rare vascular neoplasm of intermediate malignancy characterized by a complex mix of benign, low-grade, and malignant components that typically presents as a poorly circumscribed, infiltrative lesion in the skin and subcutaneous tissues.

obsolete rare acquired hemolytic anemia, a group of uncommon disorders characterized by immune or non-immune mechanisms that trigger the premature destruction of red blood cells and pose significant diagnostic and therapeutic challenges.
diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, a fast-growing and aggressive type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma that originates in B cells and typically presents as rapidly enlarging lymph nodes or masses.
obstructive jaundice, a condition where a blockage in the bile ducts prevents bile from draining from the liver to the intestines, leading to bilirubin buildup and yellowing of the skin and eyes.

tufted angioma (disease), a rare benign vascular tumor typically arising in infancy or early childhood as slowly enlarging, erythematous skin lesions often accompanied by pain, hyperhidrosis, and in some cases, Kasabach-Merritt phenomenon.

pneumocystosis, a rare but serious fungal infection caused by Pneumocystis jirovecii that primarily affects individuals with weakened immune systems, leading to pneumonia and potentially severe respiratory complications.
ulcerative colitis (disease), a chronic inflammatory bowel condition that causes ulceration and inflammation of the colon and rectum, leading to symptoms like abdominal pain and bloody diarrhea.

vesiculobullous skin disease, a mucocutaneous condition characterized by the formation of fluid-filled vesicles (small blisters) and bullae (larger blisters) arising from autoimmune, infectious, allergic, or physical triggers.

bacterial arthritis, also known as septic arthritis, is a joint infection typically caused by bacteria that leads to inflammation, pain, and potential joint damage, requiring prompt antibiotic treatment and often surgical intervention.

streptococcal toxic-shock syndrome, a rapidly progressing and potentially fatal bacterial infection that triggers shock, low blood pressure, and multi-organ failure, necessitating immediate medical intervention.

respiratory syncytial virus infectious disease, a common and seasonal respiratory infection that typically causes mild, cold-like symptoms but can lead to severe complications in infants, older adults, and those with weakened immune systems.

malignant urinary system neoplasm, a cancerous tumor arising from abnormal cell growth in the kidneys, ureters, bladder, or urethra that can invade nearby tissues and potentially spread to other parts of the body.

atypical coarctation of aorta, a rare vascular anomaly characterized by segmental narrowing of atypical aortic regions—such as the ascending aorta, the descending thoracic aorta near the diaphragm, or the abdominal aorta—that results in upper body hypertension and associated clinical complications.

gonadal dysgenesis, a disorder of the reproductive system in which the ovaries or testes fail to develop properly due to genetic, hormonal, or environmental factors, often resulting in ambiguous genitalia, infertility, or hormonal deficiencies.

tinea barbae, a rare fungal infection primarily affecting the beard and mustache areas—often transmitted through contact with infected animals—that is characterized by red, ring-shaped, inflamed lesions potentially leading to crusting and hair loss and is typically treated with oral antifungal medications and, in some cases, steroids.
osteitis fibrosa, a rare bone disorder caused by hyperparathyroidism that leads to weakened bones, cyst-like lesions, and skeletal deformities.

mucopolysaccharidosis, a group of inherited metabolic disorders caused by enzyme deficiencies that impair the breakdown of glycosaminoglycans, resulting in their accumulation and leading to multi-organ dysfunction.
mild pre-eclampsia, a pregnancy-related condition marked by elevated blood pressure and protein in the urine that necessitates careful monitoring to prevent progression and further complications.

Brill-Zinsser disease, a reactivation of epidemic typhus from dormant Rickettsia prowazekii bacteria, emerges years after the initial infection with generally milder symptoms similar to those of the original typhus.

acute leukemia (disease), a rapidly progressing blood cancer characterized by the uncontrolled proliferation of immature blood cells in the bone marrow that impairs normal cell production and requires immediate aggressive treatment.
retinitis, an inflammation of the retina that can result from infections or genetic factors and may lead to vision loss.

squamous cell lung carcinoma, a type of non-small cell lung cancer that originates from the squamous cells lining the airways and is strongly associated with smoking and other environmental risk factors.

cryptorchidism (disease), a congenital condition in which one or both testicles fail to descend into the scrotum, typically diagnosed in infancy and potentially increasing the risk of infertility and testicular cancer if not treated.

acidosis disorder, a condition in which excessive acid accumulation disrupts the body’s pH balance, potentially leading to organ damage or fatal complications due to factors like impaired oxygen delivery, kidney failure, and metabolic disturbances.

prostate adenocarcinoma, the most common form of prostate cancer, originates in the glandular epithelial cells of the prostate and is typically diagnosed via a biopsy with evaluation through measures such as the Gleason score.

disease: combined pituitary hormone deficiencies, genetic form
description: combined pituitary hormone deficiencies, genetic form, is a rare genetic disorder caused by pathogenic mutations—most commonly in the PROP1 gene—that lead to deficient production of multiple pituitary hormones essential for normal growth, metabolism, and development.

sitosterolemia, a rare autosomal recessive genetic disorder caused by mutations in the ABCG5 or ABCG8 genes that leads to excessive absorption and accumulation of plant sterols in the blood, resulting in xanthomas, atherosclerosis, and a hypercholesterolemia-like condition unresponsive to standard statin treatment.
iron deficiency anemia, a common blood disorder caused by low iron levels that reduces hemoglobin production and results in symptoms such as fatigue, pale skin, and shortness of breath.

Ewing sarcoma, a rare cancer that typically develops in the bones or soft tissues of children and young adults, often affecting the legs, pelvis, or chest wall and characterized by specific genetic changes.
hypophosphatasia, is a rare inherited metabolic bone disease characterized by impaired mineralization of bones and teeth due to defective alkaline phosphatase activity.

islet cell adenomatosis, an autosomal dominant disorder in which pancreatic islet cell hyperplasia can lead to hyperinsulinemic hypoglycemia from neuroendocrine tumors or noninsulin-dependent diabetes mellitus.
cholecystolithiasis, the formation of hardened bile deposits (gallstones) in the gallbladder that can cause pain, inflammation, and blockage of bile flow.

visual pathway disease, a disorder resulting from lesions along the visual pathway—from the retina and optic nerve through the chiasm and radiations to the visual cortex—that leads to characteristic visual field defects and impaired visual processing.

succinic semialdehyde dehydrogenase deficiency, a rare autosomal recessive neurometabolic disorder caused by mutations in the ALDH5A1 gene that impair the breakdown of GABA and lead to an accumulation of neurotoxic metabolites, manifests with developmental delays, intellectual disability, hypotonia, and seizures.
dipsogenic diabetes insipidus, a rare disorder caused by hypothalamic dysfunction that results in an unregulated thirst mechanism, leading to excessive fluid intake and frequent urination.

graft versus host disease, a complication of allogeneic stem cell or bone marrow transplants in which donor immune cells attack the recipient's tissues, potentially causing systemic inflammation and damage to multiple organs.
Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease, a group of inherited peripheral neuropathies that cause progressive muscle weakness and sensory loss.

Reynolds syndrome, a rare autoimmune disorder characterized by the combination of primary biliary cholangitis and limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis, presents with symptoms such as fatigue, pruritus, and other systemic complications.

autonomic dysreflexia, a life-threatening condition primarily affecting individuals with spinal cord injuries at or above the T6 level that causes a sudden, exaggerated increase in blood pressure due to disrupted autonomic regulation in response to stimuli below the injury.

qualitative platelet defect, a disorder in which platelets are present in normal numbers but have impaired function—such as defective adhesion, aggregation, or secretion—that leads to abnormal clotting and mucocutaneous bleeding.

disease: acute myeloid leukemia with NPM1 somatic mutations
description: acute myeloid leukemia with NPM1 somatic mutations, a distinct subtype of AML characterized by exon 12 mutations in the NPM1 gene that cause abnormal cytoplasmic localization of the nucleophosmin protein, present in about 30–35% of adult cases and associated with unique molecular, pathological, and clinical features.
learning disability, a condition that affects the brain's ability to process information and can lead to difficulties with language, reading, writing, math, and other academic skills.

subacute bacterial endocarditis, a slowly developing infection of the heart’s inner lining and valves typically caused by streptococcal bacteria that form vegetations and can lead to serious complications if untreated.

nocturnal enuresis, a condition characterized by the involuntary leakage of urine during sleep beyond the age at which bladder control is typically established, affecting both children and adults and often managed through behavioral and medical interventions.

hepatosplenic T-cell lymphoma, a rare and highly aggressive peripheral T-cell lymphoma that predominantly affects young individuals and involves the liver, spleen, and bone marrow with rapid progression and poor response to conventional therapy.

acquired hemophilia, a rare autoimmune disorder in which autoantibodies target clotting factor VIII, leading to spontaneous and potentially life-threatening bleeding in individuals without a prior bleeding history.

disease: maligant granulosa cell tumor of ovary
description: maligant granulosa cell tumor of ovary, a rare low-grade malignant ovarian tumor that accounts for about 2–5% of ovarian cancers, is a sex cord-stromal neoplasm exhibiting either adult or juvenile histopathologic types and often presents with hormonal overproduction leading to relatively favorable outcomes when detected early.
myasthenia gravis, a chronic autoimmune disorder that interrupts nerve-muscle communication and causes fluctuating weakness and fatigue in voluntary muscles.
alcoholic psychosis, a severe mental health condition marked by hallucinations and delusions that arises from heavy alcohol use, intoxication, or withdrawal.
pleural empyema (disease), an infection characterized by the accumulation of pus in the pleural space typically resulting from bacterial pneumonia.
sulfhemoglobinemia, a rare condition in which a sulfur atom irreversibly binds to hemoglobin, impairing its ability to transport oxygen and resulting in cyanosis.
arthritic joint disease, a term describing a broad group of over 100 disorders characterized by joint inflammation, pain, stiffness, and the progressive degeneration of joint tissues.
keloid formation, is an abnormal healing process where excessive collagen production results in raised, firm scars that extend beyond the original injury.

ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome, an iatrogenic complication of fertility treatments characterized by ovarian enlargement, fluid shifts, and abdominal discomfort that can range from mild symptoms to severe, life-threatening complications.

erectile dysfunction (disease), a condition characterized by a man's inability to achieve or maintain an erection sufficient for satisfactory sexual activity, often linked to underlying physical or psychological health issues.
keratoacanthoma, a rapidly growing, dome-shaped skin tumor with a central keratin plug that may spontaneously regress but can mimic squamous cell carcinoma.

autosomal recessive inherited pseudoxanthoma elasticum, a rare multisystem disorder caused by ABCC6 gene mutations that lead to abnormal mineralization and fragmentation of elastic fibers in the skin, eyes, and blood vessels.
cervical adenocarcinoma, a less common type of cervical cancer that originates in the glandular cells of the endocervix and is often linked to HPV infection.
coronary vasospasm, a condition in which the coronary arteries suddenly constrict leading to reduced blood flow, chest pain, and potentially serious complications such as arrhythmias or heart attack.
tenosynovial giant cell tumor, a rare, typically benign neoplasm arising from the synovial lining of joints, bursae, and tendon sheaths that can manifest in either localized or diffuse forms.

Pthirus pubis infestation, a parasitic infection caused by crab lice that feed on human blood and primarily affects the pubic hair area—resulting in intense itching due to an allergic reaction to louse bites and transmitted mainly through close personal contact.
uterine corpus cancer, a common gynecologic malignancy that primarily originates from the lining of the uterus as endometrial carcinoma, with a smaller proportion presenting as uterine sarcomas.

oculogastrointestinal muscular dystrophy, an extremely rare autosomal recessive neuromuscular disease characterized by ocular abnormalities such as ptosis and diplopia, followed by gastrointestinal complications including chronic diarrhea, malnutrition, and intestinal pseudo-obstruction.

esophageal varices with bleeding, a life-threatening complication where dilated veins in the esophagus rupture—typically due to liver cirrhosis and portal hypertension—resulting in massive hemorrhage that necessitates urgent endoscopic and medical intervention.

rickettsialpox, a rare bacterial infection caused by Rickettsia akari and transmitted by mites, typically presents with an eschar at the bite site followed by fever and a generalized papulovesicular rash resembling chickenpox.

lipoid nephrosis, a kidney disorder characterized by heavy proteinuria leading to nephrotic syndrome and minimal glomerular changes on light microscopy, often responding well to corticosteroid therapy.
congenital hemangioma, a fully formed vascular lesion present at birth resulting from abnormal blood vessel development that can rapidly involute, remain stable, or partially involute.

post-transplant lymphoproliferative disease, a rare and potentially fatal complication following organ or stem cell transplantation characterized by uncontrolled proliferation of lymphoid cells often driven by Epstein-Barr virus under immunosuppression.

familial chylomicronemia syndrome, a rare inherited disorder that disrupts the normal breakdown of dietary fats, leading to extremely high triglyceride levels and potentially life-threatening complications such as acute pancreatitis.

duodenal obstruction, a blockage in the duodenum—often due to congenital anomalies like annular pancreas or external compressive forces—that impairs the passage of food and fluids through the digestive tract.
autism spectrum disorder, is a neurodevelopmental condition marked by challenges in social communication, interaction, and repetitive behaviors that typically emerge in early childhood.

congenital neutropenia-myelofibrosis-nephromegaly syndrome, a rare, genetic primary immunodeficiency disorder characterized by severe congenital neutropenia, bone marrow fibrosis with extramedullary hematopoiesis (including nephromegaly), and neutrophil dysfunction unresponsive to granulocyte colony-stimulating factor, leading to life-threatening infections.
Sheehan syndrome, a rare condition resulting from severe blood loss during childbirth that damages the pituitary gland and leads to multiple hormone deficiencies.

Miyoshi myopathy, a rare autosomal recessive muscular dystrophy primarily caused by dysferlin gene mutations, typically manifests in early adulthood with progressive distal muscle weakness and atrophy, most notably in the calf muscles.
paucibacillary leprosy, a form of leprosy characterized by one to five localized skin lesions with a low bacterial load and a positive cell-mediated immune response.
muscular atrophy, a condition characterized by the wasting or loss of skeletal muscle mass due to factors such as inactivity, nerve damage, aging, malnutrition, or underlying diseases.

nasal cavity disease, a condition encompassing disorders affecting the nasal cavity—often involving structural abnormalities, infections, or growths that lead to symptoms such as nasal obstruction, chronic sinus infections, and diminished sense of smell.
esophageal varices, enlarged veins in the esophagus most often caused by liver cirrhosis and portal hypertension that can lead to life-threatening bleeding.
asthma, a chronic lung disease that causes airway inflammation, narrowing, and excess mucus production, leading to wheezing, coughing, and difficulty breathing.
folliculitis, a common inflammatory skin condition caused by bacterial, fungal, or viral infections that inflame hair follicles and result in pimple-like bumps or pustules on the skin.

Hirschsprung disease-ganglioneuroblastoma syndrome, a rare genetic disorder caused by pathogenic mutations, is characterized by developmental defects during embryogenesis that result in total or partial colonic aganglionosis alongside multifocal neuroblastic tumors.

eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome, a rare multisystem disorder characterized by severe muscle pain, skin rashes, and lung complications, often linked to elevated eosinophils and triggered by contaminated L-tryptophan supplements.

lung disease, a collective term for conditions that impair normal lung function—often due to smoking, infections, environmental factors, or genetics—and include disorders such as COPD, asthma, and lung cancer.
primary hyperoxaluria, a rare genetic metabolic disorder caused by liver enzyme deficiencies leading to excess oxalate production, recurrent kidney stones, and progressive kidney damage.

influenza, severe, susceptibility to, a condition in which a combination of genetic factors, chronic health issues, and environmental exposures increases an individual's risk of developing serious influenza complications such as acute respiratory illness and hospitalization.

X-linked severe congenital neutropenia, an X-linked recessive immunodeficiency syndrome caused by mutations in the WAS gene, is characterized by severe congenital neutropenia, monocytopenia, and recurrent, life-threatening bacterial infections beginning in infancy.

lung cancer, a malignant tumor originating in lung tissues from uncontrolled cell growth, primarily caused by smoking and environmental factors, and recognized as the leading cause of cancer-related deaths worldwide.
long QT syndrome, a heart rhythm disorder that affects the heart's electrical system and can cause irregular, potentially life-threatening arrhythmias leading to fainting or sudden death.
adrenal gland pheochromocytoma, a rare neuroendocrine tumor arising from adrenal chromaffin cells that leads to excess catecholamine production and symptoms such as high blood pressure.
cor pulmonale, a condition characterized by right ventricular enlargement and eventual failure due to pulmonary hypertension caused by chronic lung disorders.

obsolete neurogenic bladder (disease), is a condition in which nerve damage or dysfunction impairs the communication between the brain, spinal cord, and bladder, leading to abnormal urinary storage and voiding.

CD4+/CD56+ hematodermic neoplasm, a rare and highly aggressive hematologic malignancy that initially presents with distinctive skin lesions and rapidly disseminates to lymph nodes, bone marrow, and peripheral blood, is characterized by a CD4+/CD56+ (often CD123-positive) immunophenotype indicative of plasmacytoid dendritic cell origin.

endometrial cancer, a type of uterine cancer originating in the lining of the uterus that is often linked to high estrogen levels and treated through methods such as surgery, radiation, chemotherapy, or hormone therapy.
hepatitis B virus infection, a liver disease caused by the hepatitis B virus that can be acute or chronic and is spread through infected blood and body fluids.

Dravet syndrome, a rare genetic epileptic encephalopathy that begins in infancy with severe, difficult-to-control seizures and is associated with developmental delays, cognitive impairment, and behavioral challenges.
intestinal impaction, a condition in which hardened stool becomes lodged in the colon or rectum due to chronic constipation, causing severe abdominal discomfort and difficulty passing stool.

macrocytic anemia (disease), a blood disorder characterized by oversized red blood cells primarily due to deficiencies in vitamin B12 or folate, certain medications, or other underlying conditions that impair DNA synthesis and normal red blood cell production.
intestinal obstruction, a blockage that prevents food, fluids, and gas from passing through the digestive tract, potentially resulting in severe abdominal pain and life-threatening complications.
acromegaly, a rare hormonal disorder caused by excess growth hormone production after puberty that leads to abnormal enlargement of bones, tissues, and organs.

tertiary lesion of yaws, a late-stage complication of untreated yaws that typically develops 5 to 10 years after initial infection and is marked by severe, destructive lesions affecting the skin, bones, and joints.
blepharoconjunctivitis, an ophthalmic condition characterized by inflammation of both the eyelids and the conjunctiva, leading to redness, irritation, crusting, and discomfort.
black piedra, a superficial fungal infection caused by Piedraia hortae that forms small, hard black nodules on hair shafts, primarily occurring in warm, humid tropical regions.
macular retinal edema, a condition characterized by fluid leakage into the central part of the retina (the macula), leading to swelling and impaired sharp, central vision.
toxic shock syndrome, a rare but life-threatening condition caused by toxins released from staph or strep bacteria that can lead to rapid, multi-organ damage.
peptic ulcer disease, a condition characterized by open sores in the stomach or duodenum typically caused by Helicobacter pylori infection or NSAID use.
injury, a physical harm or damage to living tissue caused by external factors such as accidents, trauma, or environmental extremes.
stone in bladder diverticulum, a condition in which minerals in stagnant urine crystallize within a bladder diverticulum, potentially causing pain, hematuria, and recurrent infections.
Burkitt lymphoma, a rare and aggressive B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma characterized by rapid growth, a distinctive starry-sky pattern on pathology, and frequent association with Epstein-Barr virus.
exposure keratitis, a condition marked by corneal damage and inflammation from inadequate eyelid closure that leads to dryness, irritation, and potential ulceration and vision loss.
frozen shoulder, a condition characterized by gradually worsening shoulder pain, stiffness, and reduced motion that typically resolves within one to three years.

invasive non-typhoidal salmonellosis, a severe, life-threatening extraintestinal infection caused by non-typhoidal Salmonella serotypes that predominantly affects immunocompromised and vulnerable individuals, leading to systemic complications and high mortality.
cystitis, an inflammation of the bladder most often caused by a bacterial infection that leads to symptoms like frequent urination and discomfort and is typically treated with antibiotics.
variola major infectious disease, a severe form of smallpox caused by the variola virus that led to high fever, a progressive skin rash, and a mortality rate exceeding 30%.
ventricular tachycardia, a fast and abnormal heart rhythm originating in the heart's ventricles that can be life-threatening.
inherited lipid metabolism disorder, a genetic condition caused by enzyme deficiencies that impede the normal breakdown and utilization of lipids, leading to their abnormal accumulation in tissues.
gastric cancer, a malignant tumor that originates in the inner lining of the stomach and gradually invades its walls, often leading to symptoms like unexplained weight loss and stomach pain.
appendicitis, an inflammation of the appendix causing lower right abdominal pain, nausea, and fever that often requires urgent surgical removal to prevent serious complications.
intermittent vascular claudication, a manifestation of peripheral arterial disease characterized by exercise-induced leg muscle pain, cramping, or fatigue that is relieved by brief periods of rest.
gestational trophoblastic neoplasm, a rare malignant tumor arising from the abnormal proliferation of trophoblastic cells during or after pregnancy.
systemic sclerosis, a rare autoimmune disorder characterized by widespread fibrosis and vascular damage affecting the skin and internal organs.
endomyometritis, inflammation of the uterine lining and muscle often resulting from infection following childbirth or abortion.

neoplasm of mature B-cells, is a malignant disorder originating from mature B-lymphocytes or plasma cells that encompasses a heterogeneous spectrum of non-Hodgkin lymphomas and leukemias with variable clinical behavior and treatment strategies.

autosomal recessive distal myopathy, is a rare inherited muscular disorder that typically presents in early adulthood with progressive weakness and atrophy of the distal lower limb muscles, often accompanied by rimmed vacuoles on muscle biopsy.

staphylococcal infection, a bacterial disease caused by Staphylococcus species that can affect the skin, lungs, heart, and other organs, leading to conditions ranging from minor skin infections to serious systemic illnesses.

familial hyperprolactinemia, a rare genetic endocrine disorder characterized by persistently elevated prolactin levels in multiple family members—absent triggers like gestation, drug intake, or pituitary tumors—that results in symptoms typical of hyperprolactinemia such as menstrual irregularities and galactorrhea.
scabies, a contagious skin infestation caused by tiny mites that burrow into the skin and lay eggs, leading to intense itching and rash.

congenital osteogenesis imperfecta-microcephaly-cataracts syndrome, a rare genetic disorder characterized by osteogenesis imperfecta with multiple prenatal bone fractures, joint laxity, severe microcephaly, and bilateral cataracts.

thyroid cancer, a disease characterized by abnormal cell growth in the thyroid gland that can disrupt hormone production and potentially spread, with several variants that determine its treatment and prognosis.
Waardenburg syndrome, a group of rare genetic disorders that cause congenital hearing loss and pigmentary abnormalities affecting the hair, eyes, and skin.

familial visceral myopathy, a rare genetic disorder characterized by myopathic degeneration of the smooth muscle in the gastrointestinal and urinary tracts leading to chronic intestinal pseudo-obstruction and variable symptoms such as abdominal distension, pain, vomiting, and altered bowel and bladder function.
epithelioid hemangioendothelioma, a rare vascular tumor originating in blood vessel lining cells that can develop in various organs.
partial epilepsy, a neurological condition marked by focal seizures originating in a specific brain region that may affect or spare a person’s level of awareness.

acute neonatal citrullinemia type I, a severe autosomal recessive urea cycle disorder manifesting within days of birth with hyperammonemia, progressive lethargy, poor feeding, vomiting, seizures, and potential increased intracranial pressure.
