gastroesophageal reflux disease, a chronic condition in which stomach acid persistently flows back into the esophagus causing symptoms such as heartburn, chest pain, and esophageal irritation.
gingivitis, an inflammation of the gums caused by bacterial plaque buildup that leads to redness, swelling, and bleeding.

thallium poisoning, a severe condition caused by exposure to highly toxic thallium compounds that disrupt intracellular potassium processes and result in gastrointestinal, neurologic, and dermatologic symptoms through ingestion, inhalation, or skin contact.
scrub typhus, a mite-borne infectious disease caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi and transmitted by chigger bites, typically presenting with fever, headache, rash, and potential severe complications.
bronchiectasis, a chronic lung disease characterized by permanent airway dilation that leads to mucus accumulation and recurrent infections.

urolithiasis, a condition characterized by the formation of hard mineral and salt stones in the urinary tract—primarily in the kidneys and ureters—that can cause pain, urinary obstruction, and may require medical or surgical treatment.
sinoatrial block, a disorder in which electrical impulses originating from the sinoatrial node are delayed or blocked from reaching the atria, resulting in disrupted heart rhythms.

Yersinia infectious disease, also known as yersiniosis, is a bacterial gastrointestinal infection primarily caused by Yersinia enterocolitica or Yersinia pseudotuberculosis, often acquired by consuming contaminated or undercooked food.

acute contagious conjunctivitis, an acute eye infection that is highly contagious—typically caused by viruses like adenovirus or bacteria—and characterized by red, irritated eyes with watery or purulent discharge that spreads easily through contact with contaminated hands or surfaces.

newborn respiratory distress syndrome, is a breathing disorder primarily seen in premature infants due to underdeveloped lungs and insufficient surfactant production that causes respiratory distress shortly after birth.

infectious disease, a medical condition caused by pathogenic microorganisms such as viruses, bacteria, fungi, parasites, and prions that can spread from person to person and is managed through prevention measures like vaccination, hygiene, and appropriate treatments.

hepatic veno-occlusive disease-immunodeficiency syndrome, is a rare autosomal recessive disorder that typically presents within the first six months of life with severe combined immunodeficiency and progressive liver injury due to occlusion of small hepatic veins leading to fibrosis and hepatomegaly.

fungal infectious disease, a condition caused by pathogenic fungi that can affect the skin, nails, lungs, and other organs, ranging from mild irritation to life-threatening systemic infections, especially in individuals with weakened immune systems.

disease: double outlet right ventricle with subaortic or doubly committed ventricular septal defect with pulmonary stenosis
description: double outlet right ventricle with subaortic or doubly committed ventricular septal defect with pulmonary stenosis, a congenital heart defect where both great arteries predominantly arise from the right ventricle through a ventricular septal defect positioned beneath one or both arterial outlets, accompanied by narrowing of the pulmonary outflow tract.

granulomatous slack skin disease, a rare and indolent variant of mycosis fungoides characterized by lax, pendulous skin folds due to granulomatous T-cell infiltrates and elastic fiber loss, often seen in middle-aged adults and associated with other lymphoproliferative disorders.

disease: autosomal dominant limb-girdle muscular dystrophy type 1D (DNAJB6)
description: autosomal dominant limb-girdle muscular dystrophy type 1D (DNAJB6), is an adult-onset, slowly progressive muscle disorder caused by mutations in the DNAJB6 gene that primarily leads to proximal pelvic muscle weakness with minimal shoulder involvement and is characterized by abnormal protein aggregates in muscle fibers without significant cardiac or respiratory compromise.

thrombocytosis disease, a condition marked by an abnormally high platelet count in the blood that can result from reactive processes to underlying conditions or from primary bone marrow disorders such as essential thrombocythemia, potentially leading to complications like clot formation and bleeding.

intellectual disability, a neurodevelopmental condition characterized by significant limitations in intellectual functioning and adaptive behavior that typically emerge before age 18 and affect daily living skills.
pulmonary edema, a condition marked by the abnormal accumulation of fluid in the lungs that interferes with oxygen exchange and can lead to severe, life-threatening respiratory distress.
phlebitis, an inflammation of a vein often triggered by a blood clot, trauma, or infection that can cause pain, swelling, and redness.

severe pre-eclampsia, a life-threatening pregnancy disorder characterized by extremely high blood pressure and signs of organ dysfunction that can quickly jeopardize the health of both mother and baby and may require prompt delivery.

juvenile Huntington disease, a rare, early-onset form of Huntington’s disease that begins in childhood or adolescence and is marked by progressive motor, cognitive, and behavioral decline due to a genetic mutation in the huntingtin gene.
Down syndrome, a genetic disorder caused by an extra copy of chromosome 21 resulting in developmental delays, intellectual disability, and distinct physical features.

rhinitis, an inflammation of the nasal lining that typically results in symptoms such as congestion, sneezing, runny nose, and itching due to various triggers including allergens, irritants, and infections.
otitis externa, a common inflammatory condition of the external ear canal typically caused by bacterial or fungal infection or irritation and often linked to water exposure.
hepatorenal syndrome, is a life-threatening complication of advanced liver disease that results in rapid, functional kidney failure without intrinsic kidney damage.
cardiac tamponade, a life-threatening emergency where fluid or blood accumulates in the pericardial sac, compressing the heart and hindering its ability to fill and pump blood effectively.
nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, a kidney disorder in which the kidneys are unresponsive to antidiuretic hormone, leading to excessive urination and dehydration.
infective endocarditis, a serious infection of the heart lining and valves typically caused by bacteria or fungi that can lead to severe complications if not promptly treated.

anemia of prematurity, a condition in preterm infants characterized by normocytic, hyporegenerative anemia resulting from low erythropoietin levels, incomplete iron transfer, and blood sampling losses.

X-linked adrenoleukodystrophy, a rare genetic disorder caused by impaired peroxisomal fatty acid oxidation leading to the accumulation of very long-chain fatty acids that progressively damage the nervous system’s white matter and adrenal cortex.

balanitis, an inflammation of the glans penis (and sometimes the foreskin) commonly caused by infections, poor hygiene, or reactive arthritis that results in irritation, swelling, and sometimes lesions.

disease: non-syndromic male infertility due to sperm motility disorder
description: non-syndromic male infertility due to sperm motility disorder, is a rare genetic condition characterized by defects in the sperm’s cilia/flagella that result in absent or reduced motility in ejaculate.
candidemia, a serious bloodstream infection caused by Candida species that can lead to invasive disease with high morbidity and mortality.
neurotrophic keratopathy, a degenerative corneal condition caused by impaired nerve function leading to reduced sensation, epithelial breakdown, and potential ulceration and perforation.

obsolete left bundle branch block, is a cardiac conduction abnormality marked by a delay or blockage in the left bundle branch that alters the normal electrical activation of the left ventricle, often indicating underlying heart disease.

cervicofacial actinomycosis, is a rare, chronic, and invasive bacterial infection of the head and neck caused by Actinomyces species, typically following dental or orofacial trauma and characterized by abscess formation, tissue fibrosis, and draining sinus tracts.
epidermodysplasia verruciformis, a rare genetic skin disorder marked by wart-like lesions from persistent HPV infections and a heightened risk of developing skin cancer.

sideroblastic anemia, a disorder in which the bone marrow produces abnormal ringed sideroblasts due to impaired incorporation of iron into hemoglobin, leading to ineffective red blood cell production.

echinococcus granulosus infectious disease, a parasitic zoonosis also known as cystic echinococcosis or hydatid disease, occurs when humans ingest eggs from the dog tapeworm Echinococcus granulosus, leading to slowly growing fluid-filled cysts in organs such as the liver and lungs.

mycetoma, a chronic, progressive subcutaneous infection caused by soil-derived bacteria or fungi that form painless masses, sinus tracts, and grains and may eventually involve deeper tissues and bones.

pancytopenia, a condition characterized by abnormally low levels of red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets that can result from factors affecting bone marrow function such as infections, medications, cancers, or autoimmune diseases.
intracranial arteriosclerosis, a condition marked by plaque buildup in the brain's arteries that narrows the vessels and reduces blood flow, thereby elevating the risk of ischemic stroke.

disease: malignant non-dysgerminomatous germ cell tumor of ovary
description: malignant non-dysgerminomatous germ cell tumor of ovary, a rare malignant ovarian cancer arising from germ cells that typically presents unilaterally in adolescents with a pelvic mass, systemic symptoms such as fever and vaginal bleeding, and may involve hormonal manifestations depending on the tumor subtype.
anorexia nervosa, an eating disorder characterized by self-imposed food restriction, distorted body image, and an intense fear of weight gain that leads to dangerously low body weight.

anaplastic oligodendroglioma, a rare and aggressive WHO grade III brain tumor originating from oligodendrocytes that typically presents with seizures and is managed through surgery, radiation, and chemotherapy.
hereditary neurocutaneous angioma, is a rare autosomal dominant disorder characterized by multiple angiomatous lesions on the skin and central nervous system.

endogenous depression, a subtype of major depressive disorder arising from internal genetic and biological factors without clear external triggers and typically managed with similar treatments as other forms of depression.

Hirschsprung disease-type D brachydactyly syndrome, a rare genetic disorder characterized by Hirschsprung disease and the absence or underdevelopment of the nails and distal phalanges of the thumbs and great toes.
neoplasm of esophagus, a malignant tumor arising from the esophageal lining that progresses from early asymptomatic stages to advanced disease with potential local invasion and distant metastasis.

humoral hypercalcemia of malignancy, is a cancer-associated syndrome primarily resulting from tumor secretion of parathyroid hormone-related peptide (PTHrP) that increases osteoclastic bone resorption and elevates blood calcium levels.

albinism, a genetic disorder that reduces or eliminates melanin production, resulting in little or no pigmentation in the skin, hair, and eyes and frequently leading to vision problems and increased sensitivity to sunlight.
toxic epidermal necrolysis, a life-threatening condition marked by extensive blistering and peeling of the skin and mucous membranes, typically triggered by adverse reactions to medications.

disease: adenocarcinoma of liver and intrahepatic biliary tract
description: adenocarcinoma of liver and intrahepatic biliary tract, a rare hepatic and biliary tumor originating in the intrahepatic bile ducts that displays atypical histological and immunohistochemical features resembling both hepatocellular carcinoma and cholangiocarcinoma.
squamous cell carcinoma of colon, an extremely rare and aggressive cancer accounting for less than 1% of colorectal malignancies with limited data to guide treatment strategies.

steatorrhea (disease), a condition characterized by the excessive excretion of dietary fat in the stool—resulting in pale, bulky, and foul-smelling feces—due to malabsorption often linked to pancreatic, celiac, or liver disorders.

mycotic endocarditis, a rare but severe infection of the heart’s inner lining predominantly caused by fungal pathogens like Candida and Aspergillus, poses significant morbidity and mortality risks, especially in patients with prosthetic valves or compromised immune systems.

arthropathy, a joint disease that may or may not involve inflammation and can result from factors such as infections, blood disorders, and metabolic conditions, encompasses a range of conditions including arthritis, facet arthropathy, diabetic arthropathy, and spondyloarthritis.
denture stomatitis, a common inflammatory condition of the oral mucosa beneath dentures caused by Candida overgrowth often linked to poor denture hygiene.

trichuriasis, a parasitic disease caused by the human whipworm Trichuris trichiura that infects the large intestine when contaminated food or soil is ingested and can result in abdominal pain, diarrhea, anemia, and stunted growth.

obsolete classic mast cell leukemia, a rare and aggressive variant of systemic mastocytosis defined by ≥20% immature mast cells in the bone marrow that often leads to rapid clinical deterioration and poor prognosis.

adult idiopathic neutropenia, is a chronic condition in adults characterized by persistently low neutrophil counts for at least three months, with no identifiable cause after other potential etiologies are excluded.

monocytic leukemia, a form of myeloid leukemia characterized by an abnormal proliferation of monocytes in the blood and bone marrow that can present in both acute and chronic forms leading to immune and hematologic complications.

rhabdomyosarcoma (disease), a rare malignant soft tissue sarcoma that primarily arises in skeletal muscle, predominantly affecting children and adolescents, often spreading to the lungs, lymph nodes, and bones, and requiring a combination of surgery, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy.

disease: malignant Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor of ovary
description: malignant Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor of ovary, a rare malignant sex cord-stromal ovarian tumor typically affecting young women that often presents with androgen excess and is primarily managed by surgical resection.
inherited aplastic anemia, a rare genetic disorder in which gene defects cause the bone marrow to fail in producing sufficient blood cells.

thyroid gland carcinoma, a type of cancer that begins in the thyroid gland—a butterfly-shaped organ in the neck that regulates metabolism—which is often slow-growing and treatable when diagnosed early but can spread if it becomes more advanced.

isolated congenital growth hormone deficiency, a rare genetic disorder caused by pathogenic mutations that lead to inadequate production of growth hormone and subsequent postnatal growth failure with variable clinical severity.

chronic diarrheal disease, a condition marked by persistent loose or watery stools lasting more than four weeks, typically resulting from underlying digestive disorders, infections, or malabsorption issues that warrant medical evaluation and management.
substance-related disorder, a treatable chronic condition characterized by compulsive substance use that persists despite harmful physical, psychological, and social consequences.

actinomycosis, a rare bacterial infection caused by Actinomyces species that typically leads to abscesses, sinus tracts, and sulfur granules in various tissues including the mouth, face, lungs, and abdomen.

Finnish upper limb-onset distal myopathy, a rare genetic disorder characterized by adult-onset, slowly progressive distal-to-proximal limb muscle weakness and atrophy—initially affecting the thenar and hypothenar muscles and leading to hand clumsiness and later ambulation difficulties.
papillary adenocarcinoma, is a histological form of lung cancer characterized by malignant papillary structures that replace normal alveolar architecture through compressive, destructive growth.
proton-pump inhibitor-responsive esophageal eosinophilia, a disorder exhibiting the clinical and histologic features of eosinophilic esophagitis that resolves with proton pump inhibitor treatment.

nephrocalcinosis, a kidney disorder characterized by the abnormal deposition of calcium salts—typically calcium phosphate and/or calcium oxalate—in the renal parenchyma and tubules, often related to metabolic disturbances and potentially leading to acute or chronic kidney injury.

vascular disease, a condition affecting the network of blood vessels—including arteries, veins, and capillaries—that can lead to serious complications like heart attack, stroke, and impaired circulation.

hypereosinophilic syndrome, is a rare group of blood disorders characterized by persistently high levels of eosinophils that can infiltrate tissues and lead to potentially life-threatening organ damage.
narcolepsy without cataplexy, a chronic sleep disorder characterized by excessive daytime sleepiness in the absence of sudden muscle weakness episodes, typically with normal hypocretin levels.
paranoid schizophrenia, once categorized as a subtype of schizophrenia marked by delusions, hallucinations, and paranoia, is now recognized as part of the broader schizophrenia spectrum.
sclerosing cholangitis, a chronic inflammatory and fibrotic disorder of the bile ducts that can lead to cirrhosis and liver failure.

disease: acute myeloid leukemia and myelodysplastic syndromes related to topoisomerase type 2 inhibitor
description: acute myeloid leukemia and myelodysplastic syndromes related to topoisomerase type 2 inhibitor, are therapy-related myeloid neoplasms that typically develop 2–3 years after exposure to cytotoxic topoisomerase II inhibitors and present as overt acute leukemia—often without a preceding myelodysplastic phase—and are frequently associated with rearrangements involving the MLL gene at 11q23.

beta-thalassemia and related diseases, are inherited hemoglobin disorders caused by mutations affecting beta-globin production, which result in a spectrum of clinical manifestations from mild anemia to severe complications such as bone marrow expansion and extramedullary hematopoiesis.

breast cancer, a disease marked by the uncontrolled growth of abnormal cells in the breast tissue that can form tumors, potentially spread to other parts of the body, and is commonly diagnosed through screening and treated with a combination of surgery, radiation, chemotherapy, and hormone therapy.
Addison disease, also known as primary adrenal insufficiency, is a rare endocrine disorder characterized by inadequate production of the hormones cortisol and aldosterone due to adrenal gland damage.

angiocentric glioma, a rare pediatric-type low-grade (WHO grade I) neuroepithelial tumor predominantly affecting children and young adults that commonly presents with seizures and is generally amendable to curative surgical resection.
acute biphenotypic leukemia, a rare subtype of acute leukemia characterized by leukemic blasts coexpressing both myeloid and lymphoid markers that lead to ambiguous lineage classification.
gastric linitis plastica, is a rare and aggressive form of gastric adenocarcinoma characterized by diffuse infiltration and fibrotic thickening of the stomach wall that restricts its expansion.

primary malignant peritoneal tumor, is a rare cancer originating from the mesothelial cells lining the abdomen that often remains asymptomatic until advanced stages and is typically managed with treatments such as surgery, HIPEC, and targeted therapies.
trachoma, a bacterial eye infection caused by Chlamydia trachomatis, is the leading infectious cause of preventable blindness worldwide due to repeated cycles of inflammation and scarring.

intestinal botulism, a rare condition in which ingested Clostridium botulinum spores germinate in the intestines to produce neurotoxins that cause muscle weakness and paralysis, primarily affecting infants and occasionally adults.
gastritis, an inflammation of the stomach lining that can be acute or chronic and is commonly caused by infections, certain medications, alcohol, or other irritants.
cyclic hematopoiesis, a rare inherited disorder characterized by periodic drops in neutrophil levels that temporarily weaken the immune system and increase susceptibility to infections.

mevalonic aciduria, a rare autosomal recessive disorder caused by mevalonate kinase deficiency that disrupts cholesterol and isoprenoid biosynthesis and leads to recurrent inflammatory episodes, neurological impairments, and multisystem involvement from infancy.
pancreatic insulinoma, a rare neuroendocrine tumor arising from pancreatic beta cells that oversecretes insulin and leads to episodes of hypoglycemia.
thrombocythemia, a disorder in which the bone marrow produces too many platelets, increasing the risk of blood clots and bleeding complications.

fibrillary astrocytoma, a historical designation for the most common subtype of diffuse, low-grade astrocytoma arising from neoplastic astrocytes, typically occurring in the cerebral hemispheres of adults and characterized by fibrillary morphology with nuclear atypia but lacking high-grade features such as significant mitotic activity, necrosis, or microvascular proliferation.

acute gonococcal endometritis, an acute inflammation of the uterine lining caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection that is characterized by neutrophilic infiltration and microabscess formation and may contribute to pelvic inflammatory disease.

dilution, pigmentary, is a genetically inherited condition characterized by global hypopigmentation of the skin, hair, and eyes due to disrupted melanin production, often presenting with fine punctate or diffuse depigmentation without significant ocular dysfunction.
staphylococcal toxic-shock syndrome, an acute, life-threatening condition caused by Staphylococcus aureus toxins that rapidly trigger high fever, rash, hypotension, and multisystem organ dysfunction.
skin neoplasm, an abnormal growth on the skin that can be benign or malignant, often related to sun exposure and including forms such as basal cell carcinoma and squamous cell carcinoma.
peripheral nervous system disease, a condition that damages the nerves connecting the brain and spinal cord to the rest of the body, leading to impaired sensory, motor, and autonomic functions.
postherpetic neuralgia, a chronic complication of shingles that results in persistent nerve pain after the rash heals.

carcinoma of esophagus, is an aggressive malignancy originating in the inner lining of the esophagus, frequently associated with risk factors like smoking and alcohol use and often diagnosed at an advanced stage due to progressive dysphagia.
hepatic vein thrombosis, a condition where blood clots block the liver’s venous outflow, leading to liver congestion, damage, and potential failure.
amblyopia (disease), a developmental visual disorder in which the brain fails to properly process input from one eye, leading to reduced vision often referred to as lazy eye.

cytomegalovirus infection, a common herpesvirus that typically remains asymptomatic in healthy individuals yet can cause serious complications in pregnant women, newborns, and those with weakened immune systems.

opisthorchiasis, a parasitic foodborne infection caused by liver flukes acquired from eating raw or undercooked fish that can lead to serious liver and bile duct diseases, including cholangiocarcinoma.
substernal goiter, an enlargement of the thyroid that extends below the sternal notch into the mediastinum and may cause tracheal compression and obstructive symptoms.
pellagra, a nutritional deficiency disease caused by an inadequate intake or absorption of niacin (vitamin B3) that leads to dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia.

hepatic porphyria, a rare genetic disorder affecting the liver’s heme production that leads to toxic porphyrin buildup and causes severe neurovisceral attacks, skin reactions, and potential liver complications.

parasitic infection, a disease caused by organisms that live on or inside a host and are transmitted through contaminated food, water, blood, or insect bites, which can be prevented by proper hygiene and treated with specific medications.

trypanosomiasis, a parasitic infection caused by protozoa transmitted by blood-feeding insects such as tsetse flies, affects both humans and animals by damaging the skin, blood, lymph nodes, brain, and spinal cord.
vulvovaginal candidiasis, a common fungal infection caused primarily by Candida albicans that results in vulvar and vaginal itching, inflammation, and a thick, curdy discharge.

intracranial vasospasm, a condition characterized by a sudden or delayed narrowing of cerebral arteries—often following subarachnoid hemorrhage—that reduces blood flow and increases the risk of cerebral ischemia and infarction.

blackwater fever, a severe complication of Plasmodium falciparum malaria characterized by massive intravascular hemolysis that releases hemoglobin into the blood and urine, often resulting in anemia and high mortality.

Bell's palsy, a condition that causes sudden, often temporary, weakness or paralysis on one side of the face due to inflammation of the seventh cranial nerve, typically has an unknown cause which may be related to viral infections.
retrograde amnesia, a form of memory loss characterized by the inability to recall events and information acquired before an injury, disease, or traumatic incident occurred.
variegate porphyria, a rare genetic disorder caused by mutations affecting heme production that results in photosensitivity with chronic skin blistering and acute neurovisceral symptoms.

ectopic pregnancy, a serious condition occurring when a fertilized egg implants outside the uterus—usually in a fallopian tube—potentially leading to life-threatening complications if not treated promptly.

Huntington disease-like, a group of autosomal dominant neurodegenerative disorders that mimic Huntington's disease by producing a progressive triad of involuntary movements, cognitive decline, and psychiatric abnormalities, typically presenting in midlife with a relentlessly deteriorating course.

thyroid gland undifferentiated (anaplastic) carcinoma, is a rare and extremely aggressive thyroid cancer characterized by undifferentiated cells that rapidly invade local tissues and lead to a poor prognosis.

disease: symptomatic form of hemophilia in female carriers
description: symptomatic form of hemophilia in female carriers, a condition in which women carrying hemophilia gene mutations exhibit bleeding symptoms—such as heavy menstrual bleeding, easy bruising, and prolonged bleeding after trauma—due to reduced clotting factor levels.
corneal ulcer, an open sore on the cornea typically caused by infection, injury, or dryness that can lead to pain, scarring, and potential vision loss if not treated promptly.

ST-elevation myocardial infarction, a severe type of heart attack caused by complete coronary artery occlusion that leads to extensive myocardial ischemia and tissue necrosis with significant risks of complications and death.
vitamin B deficiency, a condition caused by inadequate intake or absorption of essential B vitamins that can result in symptoms such as fatigue, skin rash, cognitive impairment, and anemia.

relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis, a form of MS characterized by periodic flare-ups of neurologic symptoms followed by periods of partial or complete recovery due to immune-mediated damage to the central nervous system.

cystic echinococcosis, a parasitic disease caused by the larval stage of Echinococcus granulosus that forms hydatid cysts—primarily in the liver and lungs—which can grow slowly and remain asymptomatic for years.

congenital temporomandibular joint ankylosis, a rare maxillofacial disorder present at birth that causes marked limitation in mouth opening and is often associated with varying degrees of facial dysmorphism in the absence of trauma or infection.

anuria, a condition characterized by an almost complete absence of urine production—typically less than 100 milliliters per day—often indicating severe kidney dysfunction, obstruction, or other serious systemic conditions.

disease: non-acquired combined pituitary hormone deficiencies without extra-pituitary malformations
description: non-acquired combined pituitary hormone deficiencies without extra-pituitary malformations, a group of genetic endocrine disorders caused by mutations in pituitary transcription factor genes that result in deficiencies of multiple pituitary hormones while sparing other body systems.
hypertrichosis of eyelid, a benign condition characterized by excessive or abnormally long hair growth localized to the eyelid area that can be congenital or acquired, including drug-induced forms.

pancreatic insulin-producing neuroendocrine tumor, a rare tumor arising from the pancreas' hormone-producing islet cells that secrete excess insulin leading to hypoglycemia and typically exhibits slow growth and benign behavior.

ovarian cyst (disease), is a typically benign, fluid-filled sac on or within an ovary that often causes no symptoms but can sometimes lead to pain or complications if it enlarges, ruptures, or twists.
beta thalassemia, an inherited blood disorder causing reduced or absent production of beta globin chains that leads to decreased hemoglobin levels and varying severities of anemia.

upper respiratory tract disease, is an acute infectious condition affecting the nose, throat, sinuses, and larynx—typically caused by viruses and characterized by symptoms such as runny nose, cough, and sore throat.

acute myeloblastic leukemia with maturation, a subtype of acute myeloid leukemia defined by ≥20% blasts in the bone marrow or peripheral blood accompanied by evidence of granulocytic maturation (at least 10% maturing neutrophils) with limited monocytic involvement.
benign mammary dysplasia, a noncancerous condition affecting primarily women that involves abnormal growth of breast tissue resulting in lumps, discomfort, and nipple sensitivity.

hidradenitis suppurativa, a chronic inflammatory skin disorder characterized by painful, recurrent lumps, abscesses, and scarring in areas where skin rubs together such as the armpits, groin, buttocks, and under the breasts.

hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase deficiency, is a hereditary disorder of purine metabolism caused by mutations in the HPRT1 gene that disrupt purine recycling, resulting in hyperuricemia and a spectrum of neurological and behavioral abnormalities, including the classic presentation of Lesch–Nyhan syndrome.
polydipsia, a condition characterized by unquenchable thirst that can indicate underlying issues such as diabetes, dehydration, or kidney problems.
autoimmune disease, a condition in which the immune system mistakenly attacks the body's own healthy cells and tissues, leading to chronic inflammation and a range of health complications.
nocardiosis, a rare and potentially fatal infection caused by soil-dwelling Nocardia bacteria that primarily affects the lungs, brain, and skin.

systemic mastocytosis, a rare disorder characterized by the abnormal buildup and activation of mast cells in various tissues and organs, leading to histamine release, allergic reactions, and potential organ damage.

idiopathic inherited hypercalciuria, is a rare renal disorder characterized by excessive urinary calcium excretion despite normal blood calcium levels, leading to an increased risk of kidney stones, nephrocalcinosis, and reduced bone mineral density, often with a complex polygenic inheritance.

cryptosporidiosis, a parasitic infection transmitted through contaminated water, food, or contact with infected feces that primarily causes watery diarrhea and gastrointestinal symptoms, particularly in immunocompromised individuals and children.
furunculosis, is a bacterial infection of hair follicles that causes painful, red, pus-filled boils typically from Staphylococcus aureus.

non-24-hour sleep-wake syndrome, a chronic circadian rhythm disorder in which the body’s internal clock fails to align with the 24-hour day, causing daily delays in sleep onset and wake times that lead to insomnia and excessive daytime sleepiness.
angle-closure glaucoma, a type of glaucoma where the iris blocks the eye's drainage angle, leading to increased intraocular pressure that can damage the optic nerve and result in vision loss.

uterine corpus leiomyoma, benign smooth muscle tumors of the uterine wall commonly known as fibroids that affect many premenopausal women and can cause symptoms such as heavy menstrual bleeding and pelvic pressure.

pharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma, a malignant cancer originating from the squamous cells lining the pharyngeal walls—often in the oropharyngeal region—and associated with risk factors such as tobacco, alcohol use, and human papillomavirus infection.
monosomy X, a genetic condition in which females have only one X chromosome instead of two, leading to developmental and health issues such as short stature, ovarian dysfunction, and heart defects.

ear infection, a condition affecting the outer, middle, or inner ear commonly triggered by bacterial, viral, or fungal infections—often following respiratory illnesses—that leads to pain, swelling, and fluid buildup, and may require treatments such as antibiotics or pain relievers.

gastrin secretion abnormality, a disorder characterized by dysregulated production of gastrin from gastric G cells that leads to abnormal gastric acid secretion, mucosal proliferation, and digestive dysfunction, often manifesting similarly to Zollinger-Ellison syndrome but without gastrin-producing tumors.

disease: acute myeloid leukemia with t(8;16)(p11;p13) translocation
description: acute myeloid leukemia with t(8;16)(p11;p13) translocation, a rare AML subtype defined by the MYST3-CREBBP fusion that disrupts transcriptional regulation and is characterized by distinct clinicobiological features such as myelomonocytic differentiation in de novo, congenital, or therapy-related cases.

obstructive sleep apnea syndrome, a condition characterized by repeated airway blockages during sleep that lead to intermittent breathing disruptions, fragmented sleep, and increased risk of cardiovascular complications.

Pasteurella multocida infectious disease, a Gram-negative, nonmotile coccobacillus infection transmitted primarily through animal bites or scratches that can cause a spectrum of illnesses—from localized soft tissue infections to severe systemic conditions like bacteremia, meningitis, and endocarditis.

acute myeloid leukemia with t(6;9)(p23;q34), a rare AML subtype defined by the DEK::NUP214 fusion gene that is often associated with FLT3 mutations, multilineage dysplasia, bone marrow basophilia, and poor clinical outcomes.
heart cancer, an extremely rare malignancy that is usually secondary to tumors spreading from other organs, though primary types like cardiac sarcomas can also occur.

hypertensive retinopathy, a condition in which chronic high blood pressure damages the retinal blood vessels, potentially leading to vision changes and an increased risk of cardiovascular complications.

urethritis (disease), an inflammation of the urethra most often caused by bacterial infections—including sexually transmitted pathogens like gonorrhea and chlamydia—that is typically treated with antibiotics.

disease: juvenile arthritis due to defect in LACC1
description: juvenile arthritis due to defect in LACC1, is a rare autosomal recessive inflammatory arthritis that presents in early childhood with symmetric polyarthritis, elevated inflammatory markers, and variable systemic features resulting from mutations in the LACC1 gene that impair immune-metabolic and autophagic functions.
toxic labyrinthitis, an inflammation of the inner ear's membranous labyrinth caused by toxic or ototoxic substances that results in vertigo, hearing loss, and other balance-related symptoms.

disease: peripheral T-cell lymphoma, not otherwise specified
description: peripheral T-cell lymphoma, not otherwise specified, is a heterogeneous and aggressive subtype of mature T-cell lymphomas that encompasses cases not fitting into any more specific category, most commonly affecting older adults.
cystinosis, a rare genetic lysosomal storage disorder caused by mutations in the CTNS gene that leads to cystine accumulation in cells, damaging primarily the kidneys and eyes.

disease: theca steroid-producing cell malignant tumor of ovary, not further specified
description: theca steroid-producing cell malignant tumor of ovary, not further specified, is a rare malignant sex cord-stromal neoplasm of uncertain histological lineage that typically occurs in adult women and often manifests with androgen excess symptoms such as hirsutism, hair loss, and menstrual irregularities.
porphyria cutanea tarda, a disorder caused by a deficiency of uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase that leads to fragile, photosensitive skin with blistering, scarring, and potential liver abnormalities.

acute lymphoblastic leukemia (disease), is a rapidly progressing blood and bone marrow cancer characterized by the uncontrolled production of immature lymphocytes that disrupt normal blood cell function.

myeloid leukemia, a cancer of the blood and bone marrow that originates from myeloid cells and is characterized by the rapid proliferation of immature blasts, leading to ineffective blood cell production and potential bone marrow failure.

typical hemolytic-uremic syndrome, an acute thrombotic microangiopathy most often triggered by Shiga toxin-producing bacteria that leads to microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute kidney injury.
lupus erythematosus, a chronic autoimmune disease that causes inflammation and damage in multiple organs and tissues.

factor VII deficiency, a rare bleeding disorder caused by a reduced level or activity of the clotting protein factor VII that impairs normal blood clotting and leads to variable bleeding manifestations.
purulent otitis media, an infection of the middle ear characterized by purulent discharge often resulting from a perforated tympanic membrane.

disease: acute myeloid leukemia with CEBPA somatic mutations
description: acute myeloid leukemia with CEBPA somatic mutations, a subtype of AML characterized by clonal proliferation of myeloid blasts harboring recurrent somatic alterations in the CEBPA gene that confer distinct clinical and prognostic features.
neuroepithelial neoplasm, a low-grade brain tumor composed of mixed neuronal and glial cells that typically occurs in children and adolescents and is often associated with seizures.

myotonia congenita, a genetic neuromuscular disorder characterized by delayed muscle relaxation that causes stiffness and sometimes enlargement of muscles, typically presenting in childhood and classified into the Thomsen and Becker types.
seborrheic keratosis, a common benign skin growth that appears waxy or scaly and can be brown, black, or tan.
sarcoma, a rare cancer that originates in the bones and soft tissues, such as muscles, fat, nerves, and blood vessels, and is typically treated with surgery, radiation, or systemic therapies.

oculocerebral hypopigmentation syndrome, Cross type, is a rare congenital disorder characterized by reduced pigmentation of the skin, hair, and eyes, combined with various ocular anomalies, growth deficiency, severe intellectual disability, and progressive neurologic abnormalities such as spastic tetraplegia.
ocular pemphigoid, a rare autoimmune disorder that causes chronic conjunctivitis and progressive scarring of the eye's conjunctiva, potentially leading to severe vision loss.

classic Hodgkin lymphoma, lymphocyte-rich type, is a rare subtype of Hodgkin lymphoma defined by scattered Hodgkin/Reed-Sternberg cells embedded in a background dominated by small lymphocytes, often presenting in early stages with an excellent prognosis.
vernal keratoconjunctivitis, a chronic, seasonal allergic inflammation of the conjunctiva and cornea that causes intense eye itching, redness, and potential vision complications.

brucellosis, a zoonotic bacterial infection transmitted through contact with infected animals or unpasteurized dairy products that causes fever, joint pain, and potentially severe complications in various organ systems.
idiopathic hypereosinophilic syndrome, a rare blood disorder of unknown cause characterized by persistently elevated eosinophil levels that lead to tissue and organ damage.
familial prostate carcinoma, an inherited form of prostate cancer driven by genetic mutations that increase disease risk and often lead to earlier onset within affected families.

antithrombin III deficiency, a rare inherited or acquired blood clotting disorder characterized by reduced antithrombin activity that increases the risk of thrombosis, including deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism.

neurosyphilis, a serious complication of syphilis caused by the invasion of Treponema pallidum into the central nervous system, manifests in various neurological symptoms and requires timely diagnosis and treatment.

astrocytoma (excluding glioblastoma), is a type of brain tumor arising from astrocytes that can range from benign to malignant forms and is typically managed with surgery, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy.

X-linked Emery-Dreifuss muscular dystrophy, a rare X-linked genetic disorder caused by mutations in the EMD gene that results in early joint contractures, progressive muscle weakness, and cardiac conduction defects.

dominant beta-thalassemia, is an autosomal dominant blood disorder caused by mutations in the beta-globin gene that lead to the production of unstable beta-globin variants forming inclusion bodies in red blood cell precursors and resulting in ineffective erythropoiesis and a thalassemia intermedia phenotype.

penicilliosis, an opportunistic systemic fungal infection caused by Talaromyces marneffei that predominantly affects immunocompromised individuals in Southeast Asia, presenting with skin lesions, fever, and multiple organ involvement.
ischemic colitis, an inflammatory bowel condition caused by reduced blood flow to the colon leading to pain, bleeding, and diarrhea.

primary non-gestational choriocarcinoma of ovary, is an extremely rare malignant germ cell tumor arising de novo from primordial germ cells that rapidly grows, produces high levels of human chorionic gonadotropin, and metastasizes aggressively.

HIV infectious disease, a condition caused by a retrovirus transmitted through sexual contact, contaminated needles, and from mother to child, gradually weakens the immune system and can progress to AIDS if left untreated.
lipodystrophy, a disorder in which the body improperly stores fat, resulting in the loss or abnormal distribution of adipose tissue that can lead to serious metabolic complications.

meningococcal infection, a serious and potentially fatal disease caused by the bacterium Neisseria meningitidis that can lead to meningitis and bloodstream infections, necessitating prompt medical treatment.
idiopathic uveitis, a condition characterized by inflammation of the eye's uveal tract without an identifiable underlying cause.
meningococcemia, a severe and potentially fatal blood infection caused by Neisseria meningitidis that can lead to meningitis, sepsis, shock, and skin lesions.
dermatomycosis, a superficial fungal infection of the skin, hair, or nails typically caused by keratinophilic fungi that is often managed with topical or oral antifungal treatments.

systemic lupus erythematosus (disease), a chronic autoimmune disorder in which the immune system mistakenly attacks healthy tissues throughout the body, causing widespread inflammation and damage to joints, skin, kidneys, heart, lungs, and other organs.
blood coagulation disease, a disorder affecting the blood's clotting system that can lead to either excessive bleeding or abnormal clot formation.

low phospholipid associated cholelithiasis, is a rare genetic disorder caused by ABCB4 mutations that impair phosphatidylcholine secretion into bile, leading to intrahepatic stone formation and recurrent biliary symptoms typically in patients under 40.
phototoxic dermatitis, a non-immunological skin reaction that develops when phototoxic agents and specific wavelengths of light interact, leading to localized inflammation and sunburn-like symptoms.

prostate cancer, a malignant tumor that originates in the prostate gland—a small walnut-shaped organ involved in semen production—and can spread to nearby tissues and distant organs, making it one of the most common cancers in men.
oral candidiasis, a fungal infection of the mouth caused by an overgrowth of Candida species that typically presents with creamy white or red patches and soreness on the tongue and inner cheeks.
erythrasma, a superficial skin infection caused by the bacterium Corynebacterium minutissimum that presents as scaly, reddish-brown patches in skin folds.
postinflammatory pulmonary fibrosis, a chronic lung condition where prior inflammation leads to scarring of lung tissue that progressively hinders normal respiratory function.
tooth disease, a condition affecting the teeth and supporting tissues that includes decay, infections, and gum inflammation which can lead to pain and tooth loss if left untreated.
farmer's lung disease, an occupational hypersensitivity pneumonitis caused by inhaling mold spores and crop dust that can result in acute flu-like symptoms and progressive chronic lung damage.

anterior ischemic optic neuropathy, a condition characterized by reduced blood flow to the optic nerve head that leads to sudden vision loss and can present as either non-arteritic or arteritic forms.

torsades de pointes, a rare form of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia characterized by a twisting pattern of QRS complexes around the isoelectric line and associated with a prolonged QT interval that can lead to sudden cardiac death.

congenital hypothyroidism, a thyroid hormone deficiency present at birth that can lead to irreversible neurological damage and intellectual disability if not promptly treated through early diagnosis and lifelong hormone replacement.
retinal detachment, an emergency eye condition where the retina pulls away from the underlying tissue, potentially causing partial or complete vision loss.

seminoma, a type of testicular cancer originating in male germ cells located in the seminiferous tubules, is typically slow-growing and highly treatable with a survival rate above 95% when detected early.
papillary conjunctivitis, an inflammatory condition of the inner eyelid marked by red, swollen tissue with bumps caused by chronic irritation from contact lenses, foreign bodies, or trauma.
familial intrahepatic cholestasis, a rare autosomal recessive disorder causing defective bile secretion that leads to progressive cholestasis, liver damage, and eventual liver failure.
keratoconus, a progressive corneal disorder characterized by thinning and a cone-like bulging of the cornea that leads to irregular astigmatism and impaired vision.
Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome, a rare autoimmune disorder that impairs neuromuscular junction signaling and leads to progressive muscle weakness, is often associated with small-cell lung cancer.
Kostmann syndrome, a rare genetic disorder characterized by severe congenital neutropenia that predisposes affected individuals to frequent, life-threatening bacterial infections.

Rickettsiosis, a group of infectious diseases caused by intracellular Rickettsia bacteria and transmitted by arthropod vectors such as ticks and mites, typically presents with fever, headache, and rash.
Diamond-Blackfan anemia, a rare congenital disorder caused by genetic mutations that impair red blood cell production and can lead to anemia and physical abnormalities.
xerophthalmia, a condition caused by vitamin A deficiency that leads to a range of eye problems—from dry eyes and night blindness to corneal damage and potential irreversible blindness.

heart failure, a condition in which the heart is unable to pump enough blood to meet the body's needs, often resulting in symptoms like shortness of breath, fatigue, and swelling due to underlying cardiac abnormalities.
epilepsy, a chronic neurological disorder marked by recurrent, unprovoked seizures resulting from abnormal electrical activity in the brain.

growth hormone insensitivity syndrome, a genetic disorder in which normal or elevated growth hormone levels fail to elicit the proper biological response, leading to severe growth failure and markedly short stature.

staphylococcal scarlet fever, a rare infectious disease mediated by Staphylococcus aureus toxins that presents with fever, malaise, and a tender, scarlatiniform rash accentuated in the flexural areas which later evolves into desquamation.

penile cancer, a rare malignant disease that starts in the skin or tissues of the penis—typically as squamous cell carcinoma—and often manifests with skin changes, lumps, or lesions requiring timely diagnosis and treatment.
vulvitis, an inflammation of the vulva often caused by infections, irritants, or allergic reactions that results in redness, swelling, and discomfort.
myelodysplastic syndrome, a group of bone marrow cancers in which abnormal blood cell development leads to ineffective hematopoiesis and reduced production of healthy blood cells.

disease: malignant dysgerminomatous germ cell tumor of ovary
description: malignant dysgerminomatous germ cell tumor of ovary, the most common malignant ovarian germ cell tumor typically affecting adolescents and young women, presents as a pelvic mass often with systemic symptoms such as fever, vaginal bleeding, and acute abdomen, may be bilateral or associated with dysgenetic gonads, and is characterized by elevated serum tumor markers and responsiveness to chemotherapy and radiotherapy.
congenital generalized lipodystrophy, a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by near-total absence of body fat from birth that leads to severe metabolic complications.
megaesophagus, a disorder where the esophagus becomes abnormally enlarged and loses its ability to effectively propel food and liquids into the stomach.

urinary tract obstruction, a condition where a blockage anywhere along the urinary system— from the kidneys to the urethra—impedes the normal flow of urine, potentially leading to complications such as infection and kidney damage.

drug-induced liver injury, is an adverse reaction to medications or supplements that causes liver damage ranging from mild enzyme elevations to acute liver failure, and is primarily diagnosed by excluding other causes of liver disease.

melanoacanthoma, a rare, benign cutaneous neoplasm typically seen in older adults that presents as a pigmented, slow-growing nodule characterized by the proliferation of keratinocytes and dendritic melanocytes, often considered a heavily pigmented variant of seborrheic keratosis.

chlamydia trachomatis infectious disease, a common sexually transmitted bacterial infection that often presents asymptomatically yet can lead to serious reproductive and ocular complications if untreated.

heart conduction disease, a disorder affecting the heart's electrical system that impairs the regulation of heartbeat rhythm and rate and can lead to irregular rhythms, syncope, and increased risk of cardiac arrest.
pulmonary emphysema, a chronic lung disease characterized by the permanent enlargement and destruction of the alveoli, which leads to progressive breathing difficulties.

postmenopausal osteoporosis, a bone disease that occurs in women after menopause due to estrogen deficiency leading to accelerated bone loss, weakened bone density, and an increased risk of fractures.
cardiomyopathy, a disease of the heart muscle that impairs its ability to pump blood effectively and can lead to heart failure, arrhythmias, or sudden death.
diarrheal disease, a gastrointestinal condition predominantly caused by contaminated food and water that leads to severe dehydration and is a major contributor to child mortality worldwide.

familial glucocorticoid deficiency, is a rare autosomal recessive disorder in which the adrenal glands fail to produce sufficient glucocorticoids—mainly cortisol—resulting in symptoms such as neonatal hyperpigmentation, hypoglycemia, failure to thrive, and recurrent infections.

histoplasmosis, a fungal infection caused by inhaling spores of Histoplasma capsulatum found in soil contaminated with bird or bat droppings that primarily affects the lungs but can sometimes spread to other organs.

female reproductive organ cancer, an umbrella term for cancers originating in a woman's reproductive organs—including the uterus, ovaries, cervix, vagina, and vulva—that often present with symptoms such as abnormal bleeding and pelvic pain and may require treatments like surgery, radiation, or chemotherapy.

achalasia (disease), is a rare esophageal motility disorder characterized by the failure of the lower esophageal sphincter to relax and impaired peristalsis, leading to difficulty swallowing, chest pain, and food retention.
localized scleroderma, a rare skin disease characterized by thickening and hardening of the skin due to excessive collagen deposition without internal organ involvement.
lytic metastatic bone lesion, a form of cancer spread to the bones that causes localized bone destruction visible as ill-defined, lucent areas with thinning or loss of trabeculae on imaging.

constrictive pericarditis (disease), is a condition characterized by chronic inflammation that leads to thickening, scarring, and often calcification of the pericardium, restricting ventricular filling and causing diastolic dysfunction and heart failure.

Stargardt disease, a genetic retinal disorder that affects the macula, leads to progressive central vision loss due to the accumulation of lipofuscin, typically manifesting in childhood or adolescence.
pleurisy, an inflammation of the pleura—the lining of the lungs and chest cavity—that causes sharp chest pain, particularly when breathing, coughing, or sneezing.

severe combined immunodeficiency (disease), a rare, life‑threatening genetic disorder in which infants are born with little to no immune function, rendering them extremely susceptible to severe infections.

T-lymphoblastic lymphoma, an aggressive cancer originating from immature T cells in the thymus, typically affects teenagers and young adults and may exhibit features overlapping with acute lymphoblastic leukemia.

severe early-childhood-onset retinal dystrophy, an inherited retinal disorder characterized by severe congenital night blindness, progressive retinal degeneration, and nystagmus that leads to markedly impaired visual acuity beginning in early childhood.

pasteurellosis, a zoonotic bacterial infection caused by Pasteurella species, typically transmitted through animal bites or scratches, that can lead to a range of symptoms from localized skin infections to severe systemic disease.
pemphigus, a rare autoimmune disorder in which the immune system mistakenly attacks cell adhesion proteins in the skin and mucous membranes, causing painful blisters.

acute coronary syndrome, a spectrum of conditions resulting from a sudden reduction in blood flow to the heart—commonly due to a blockage or plaque rupture in the coronary arteries—that can lead to unstable angina or myocardial infarction.

rhabdomyolysis (disease), a condition characterized by the rapid breakdown of skeletal muscle fibers that release toxic intracellular contents into the bloodstream, potentially causing severe electrolyte imbalances, renal failure, and systemic complications.
dyshidrosis, a skin condition that causes small, fluid-filled, itchy blisters on the palms, fingers, and soles of the feet.

pituitary dwarfism, a condition caused by insufficient production of growth hormone by the pituitary gland that leads to slow growth, short stature, and metabolic irregularities in affected individuals.
X-linked scapuloperoneal muscular dystrophy, a rare inherited muscular dystrophy marked by late-onset weakness and wasting of shoulder blade and lower leg muscles often resulting in scapular winging.
imperforate anus, a congenital defect where the anus is absent, blocked, or malformed, disrupting normal bowel movements and typically requiring surgical intervention.

pyruvate dehydrogenase E3 deficiency, is a rare genetic disorder caused by mutations in the E3 subunit of the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex that leads to impaired mitochondrial carbohydrate metabolism manifesting as early-onset lactic acidosis, developmental delays, and variable neurological or hepatic dysfunction.

disease: osteogenesis imperfecta with opalescent teeth, blue sclerae and wormian bones but without fractures
description: osteogenesis imperfecta with opalescent teeth, blue sclerae and wormian bones but without fractures, is a hereditary connective tissue disorder characterized by dentinogenesis imperfecta presenting as opalescent teeth, blue-tinted sclerae, and the presence of wormian bones, yet notably lacking the bone fragility and frequent fractures seen in other forms of osteogenesis imperfecta.

disseminated candidiasis, a severe systemic Candida infection that spreads via the bloodstream to involve multiple organs—most notably the liver and spleen—and is commonly seen in immunocompromised patients, particularly those recovering from prolonged neutropenia.
vitiligo, a chronic autoimmune disorder that causes loss of skin pigment in patches due to the destruction of melanocytes.

pulmonary venoocclusive disease, a rare and fatal form of pulmonary hypertension caused by progressive fibrous blockage of the small pulmonary veins that leads to elevated lung arterial pressures and right-sided heart failure.
oligoastrocytoma, a rare brain tumor composed of both astrocytic and oligodendroglial cells that disrupt normal brain function and can lead to neurological symptoms.

progressive familial heart block, a genetic heart conduction disorder that gradually worsens from partial to complete electrical blockage of the heart, leading to arrhythmias, bradycardia, and potentially life-threatening complications.

venous insufficiency (disease), a condition in which weakened or damaged leg veins fail to effectively return blood to the heart, resulting in blood pooling, increased venous pressure, and symptoms such as swelling and skin changes.

disease: autosomal dominant limb-girdle muscular dystrophy type 1E (DES)
description: autosomal dominant limb-girdle muscular dystrophy type 1E (DES), is a rare genetic disorder characterized by an adult-onset, slowly progressive weakness of the proximal, pelvic, and shoulder girdle muscles with minimal cardiac or respiratory involvement.
pinta disease, a rare infectious skin condition caused by Treponema bacteria that produces scaly lesions and pigmentary changes through direct skin-to-skin contact and is treatable with antibiotics.

lower respiratory tract disease, a group of infections and inflammatory conditions affecting the lungs and airways below the voice box—such as pneumonia, bronchitis, and RSV-related illnesses—is a major cause of global morbidity and mortality, particularly among young children, the elderly, and those with underlying health issues.
autoimmune hepatitis, a chronic liver disease in which the immune system attacks liver cells, leading to inflammation and potential liver damage.
narcolepsy-cataplexy syndrome, a chronic neurological disorder characterized by excessive daytime sleepiness and sudden, emotion-triggered episodes of muscle weakness.

superior limbic keratoconjunctivitis, a chronic and recurrent inflammatory eye condition affecting the superior limbus, bulbar, and tarsal conjunctiva that leads to symptoms such as irritation, redness, photophobia, and a foreign body sensation.

arteriovenous hemangioma/malformation, a rare benign vascular lesion characterized by abnormal communications between arteries and veins that combines features of high-flow malformations and hemangiomas.

cryptococcosis, a potentially fatal fungal infection caused by inhaling Cryptococcus spores from the environment that primarily affects the lungs and brain, especially in immunocompromised individuals.
mastocytosis, a rare disorder characterized by the abnormal accumulation and activation of mast cells in various tissues that can trigger allergic reactions and potential organ complications.

keratinization disease, a heterogeneous group of disorders arising from genetic or autoinflammatory disruptions in the normal skin cornification process that lead to abnormal keratin production, inflammation, and tissue fragility.

disease: short stature due to isolated growth hormone deficiency with X-linked hypogammaglobulinemia
description: short stature due to isolated growth hormone deficiency with X-linked hypogammaglobulinemia, a rare X-linked recessive disorder characterized by pan-hypogammaglobulinemia and isolated growth hormone deficiency that leads to proportionate short stature, delayed bone age, and a favorable response to growth hormone treatment.

multibacillary leprosy, a severe form of Hansen’s disease characterized by widespread skin lesions, thickened peripheral nerves, and potential involvement of other organs, treated with a 12‐month multidrug regimen of rifampicin, dapsone, and clofazimine while requiring careful monitoring for immune reactions.

boutonneuse fever, a tick-borne rickettsial infection caused by Rickettsia conorii that typically presents with fever, a papular (spotty) rash, and skin lesions, is endemic to the Mediterranean region and treatable with antibiotics.
diabetic macular edema, a diabetes-related eye condition where fluid accumulation causes swelling in the central retina, leading to vision impairment.

optic neuritis, an inflammation of the optic nerve that causes pain, vision loss, and color distortion, often serving as an early indicator of multiple sclerosis and other autoimmune or infectious conditions.

gastrointestinal stromal tumor, a type of cancer originating from specialized cells in the walls of the digestive tract—most commonly in the stomach and small intestine—that can range from benign to malignant.

disease: distal myopathy with vocal cord weakness
description: distal myopathy with vocal cord weakness, is an adult-onset, autosomal dominant disorder characterized by initial distal limb weakness that gradually progresses to involve proximal muscles and is accompanied by vocal, pharyngeal, and often respiratory dysfunction.
sympathetic paraganglioma, a rare, highly vascular neuroendocrine tumor originating from neural crest-derived cells of the extra-adrenal sympathetic ganglia that may secrete catecholamines.

autosomal recessive familial Mediterranean fever, is a genetic autoinflammatory disorder caused by mutations in the MEFV gene that leads to recurrent episodes of fever and serosal inflammation affecting the abdomen, chest, or joints, and may result in complications such as amyloidosis.
cervical carcinosarcoma, a rare and aggressive malignant tumor of the cervix composed of both carcinomatous and sarcomatous elements that typically presents with abnormal vaginal bleeding.
urea cycle disorder, a genetic metabolic condition caused by enzyme deficiencies that impair the liver's ability to convert ammonia into urea, leading to toxic ammonia accumulation in the blood.
enterobiasis, a common parasitic infection caused by the pinworm Enterobius vermicularis that lives in the intestines and causes symptoms such as anal itching and disturbed sleep.

hyperinsulinism (disease), is a disorder characterized by the excessive secretion of insulin by the pancreatic beta cells, leading to persistent low blood sugar levels that can result from congenital genetic mutations or insulin-producing tumors.
motor nerve neuritis, a rare immune-mediated disorder that selectively damages motor nerves—resulting in progressive, asymmetric weakness without sensory loss due to nerve conduction block.

familial mitral valve prolapse, a heritable form of mitral valve disease characterized by abnormal myxomatous degeneration of the valve leaflets that leads to their displacement, mitral regurgitation, and an increased risk of complications including heart failure and sudden death.

hereditary site-specific ovarian cancer syndrome, is an inherited condition in which ovarian cancer arises from germline mutations in various genes—often alongside increased risks for other cancers—and is frequently considered part of or overlapping with the broader hereditary breast and ovarian cancer syndrome.
idiopathic urticaria, a chronic condition characterized by recurrent hives and swelling lasting more than six weeks without an identifiable trigger.

temperature-sensitive oculocutaneous albinism type 1, an extremely rare form of oculocutaneous albinism caused by temperature-sensitive tyrosinase activity that produces darker pigmentation in cooler body regions and lighter pigmentation in warmer areas, often accompanied by visual abnormalities such as nystagmus and reduced visual acuity.

tardive dyskinesia (disease), is an involuntary movement disorder primarily caused by long-term use of dopamine receptor-blocking medications, characterized by repetitive, uncontrolled muscle movements, especially in the face and tongue.

pituitary gland adenoma, a benign tumor of the hormone-secreting anterior pituitary gland that can cause hormonal imbalances and other symptoms and is typically managed with surgery, medication, or radiation.

atherosclerosis, a chronic inflammatory disease characterized by the buildup of cholesterol-rich plaque in arteries that narrows blood flow and heightens the risk of heart attacks, strokes, and other serious vascular complications.
gestational diabetes, a type of diabetes diagnosed during pregnancy that leads to elevated blood sugar levels and can increase health risks for both the mother and baby.
tinea unguium, a common fungal nail infection primarily caused by dermatophytes that leads to nail discoloration, thickening, and separation.

rheumatoid arthritis, a chronic autoimmune disorder that causes persistent inflammation predominantly in the joints, leading to pain, swelling, and potential damage to both joints and other body systems.

cirrhosis of liver, a chronic liver disease characterized by irreversible scarring and reduced liver function due to long-term damage from conditions such as hepatitis, alcohol misuse, or fatty liver disease.
hepatic coma, a severe form of hepatic encephalopathy caused by liver failure that leads to toxic buildup in the blood, resulting in profound brain dysfunction and loss of consciousness.

astroblastoma, a rare glial tumor of the central nervous system primarily affecting children and young adults, is characterized by controversial origins, variable grading, and symptoms such as headache and seizures.
mongolian spot, a benign congenital blue-gray birthmark commonly seen on the lower back or buttocks of newborns that typically fades with age.

disease: T-cell/histiocyte rich large B cell lymphoma
description: T-cell/histiocyte rich large B cell lymphoma, a rare variant of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, is characterized by sparse malignant B cells amid an abundant reactive infiltrate of T cells and histiocytes often associated with aggressive clinical behavior.
muscular dystrophy, a group of genetic disorders that cause progressive muscle weakness, degeneration, and loss of muscle mass.

familial thyroid carcinoma, a heritable form of thyroid cancer that occurs in two or more first‐degree relatives and encompasses both medullary and non-medullary subtypes often associated with distinct genetic predispositions and, in some cases, aggressive clinical behavior.

amoebiasis due to Entamoeba histolytica, a parasitic infection acquired by ingesting cysts from contaminated food or water that ranges from asymptomatic colonization to severe intestinal disease and potential extraintestinal complications such as liver abscesses.

gastrointestinal anthrax, an infection acquired by ingesting undercooked meat contaminated with Bacillus anthracis spores that leads to ulceration, bleeding, and systemic symptoms such as abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea.

tetanus, a serious bacterial infection caused by Clostridium tetani that produces a toxin leading to painful muscle spasms, particularly in the jaw and neck, and can be life-threatening without vaccination.

leprosy, a chronic infectious disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae and Mycobacterium lepromatosis that primarily affects the skin, peripheral nerves, and eyes, potentially leading to nerve damage and disfigurement if untreated.
lysosomal lipid storage disorder, an inherited metabolic condition characterized by deficient lysosomal enzyme activity that leads to the abnormal buildup of complex lipids in cells and tissues.

photoparoxysmal response, an abnormal electroencephalographic reaction to intermittent photic stimulation characterized by epileptiform discharges such as spikes and spike-wave patterns that may trigger photosensitive seizures.

peripheral primitive neuroectodermal tumor, a rare and highly aggressive malignant small round cell tumor of neural crest origin that typically affects children and young adults, often presenting as large soft tissue masses with a poor prognosis.
pigmented villonodular synovitis, a rare benign proliferative disorder of the synovium that causes painful joint swelling and can lead to progressive joint damage.

tonsillitis, an inflammation of the tonsils typically caused by viral or bacterial infections that leads to symptoms such as sore throat, swollen tonsils, difficulty swallowing, and sometimes fever and tender neck lymph nodes.

disease: acute myeloid leukemia with minimal differentiation
description: acute myeloid leukemia with minimal differentiation, a rare AML subtype characterized by poorly differentiated myeloid blasts that lack morphologic and cytochemical evidence of myeloid differentiation and require immunophenotyping for accurate diagnosis.

schistosomiasis, a parasitic disease caused by Schistosoma flatworms transmitted through contact with contaminated freshwater, leads to acute and chronic symptoms affecting the urinary tract or intestines, such as abdominal pain, diarrhea, and blood in the urine or stool.
Gilbert syndrome, a common genetic disorder that impairs the liver’s ability to process bilirubin and often causes occasional mild jaundice, is typically benign.

personality disorder, a set of enduring mental health conditions marked by inflexible, maladaptive patterns of thinking, behavior, and inner experience that significantly impair relationships, work, and overall quality of life.
obsolete familial combined hyperlipidemia, is a hereditary lipid disorder characterized by variable and fluctuating elevations of cholesterol and triglycerides that increase cardiovascular risk.

hypokalemic periodic paralysis, a rare genetic channelopathy characterized by episodic muscle weakness or paralysis triggered by low blood potassium levels, often precipitated by factors such as high-carbohydrate meals or strenuous exercise.
diphtheritic myocarditis, a toxin-mediated complication of diphtheria that causes conduction abnormalities, heart failure, and cardiogenic shock with high mortality if untreated.

intracranial thrombosis, a serious condition where a blood clot forms in the brain’s venous system, obstructing normal blood drainage and potentially leading to increased intracranial pressure, hemorrhage, and stroke-like symptoms.

rheumatic heart disease, a condition characterized by permanent heart valve damage resulting from an autoimmune response triggered by untreated or inadequately treated Group A streptococcal infections.
aspergillosis, a fungal infection caused by Aspergillus mold that primarily affects the lungs and other organs, especially in individuals with weakened immune systems or pre-existing lung conditions.

protoplasmic astrocytoma, a rare variant of diffuse low-grade astrocytoma characterized by microcystic histology with sparse glial filament expression and process-poor neoplastic astrocytes that is no longer recognized as a distinct entity in current classifications.

intellectual disability-hyperkinetic movement-truncal ataxia syndrome, a rare genetic disorder characterized by global developmental delay, microcephaly, mild to moderate intellectual disability, truncal ataxia, hyperkinetic (choreiform) movements, and elevated serum creatine kinase levels.

wound botulism, is a rare, life-threatening infection in which Clostridium botulinum spores infect a wound and produce a neurotoxin that disrupts nerve function, leading to muscle weakness, paralysis, and potentially respiratory failure.
endometrial hyperplasia, a condition in which the uterine lining becomes abnormally thick due to hormonal imbalance, often leading to irregular bleeding and an increased risk of cancer.
bilineal acute myeloid leukemia, a rare form of acute leukemia defined by the simultaneous presence of distinct myeloid and lymphoid clonal populations at diagnosis.

potassium deficiency disease, a condition marked by abnormally low blood potassium levels (hypokalemia) that can lead to muscle weakness, fatigue, gastrointestinal issues, and heart rhythm abnormalities due to factors such as medication use, gastrointestinal loss, or impaired absorption.

thrombocytopenia due to immune destruction, an autoimmune disorder in which autoantibodies and immune cells target platelets—resulting in their increased destruction, impaired production, low platelet counts, and a heightened risk of bleeding.

Clostridium infectious disease, refers to a spectrum of illnesses caused by anaerobic, Gram-positive, spore-forming bacteria that produce potent exotoxins, resulting in conditions ranging from mild food poisoning and antibiotic-associated diarrhea to severe colitis, soft-tissue infections, and life-threatening neurotoxicities such as botulism.
nephrolithiasis, a condition in which hard deposits of minerals and salts form in the kidneys or urinary tract, often causing severe pain, infection, and potential complications.
antiphospholipid syndrome, an autoimmune disorder characterized by persistent antiphospholipid antibodies that increase the risk of blood clots and pregnancy complications.
glomus tumor, a rare neoplasm originating from the glomus body and most commonly found in the subungual regions, characterized by severe pain, bluish discoloration, and cold sensitivity.
liver failure, a condition in which the liver loses its ability to perform vital functions due to severe acute or chronic damage from factors such as toxins, hepatitis, or autoimmune disorders.
glomerulonephritis, an inflammatory disorder affecting the kidney's filtering units (glomeruli) that can lead to scarring and eventual kidney failure.
fatty liver disease, a condition in which excess fat accumulates in the liver that can lead to inflammation, scarring, cirrhosis, and even liver cancer.

manic bipolar affective disorder, a chronic mental health condition characterized by alternating episodes of intense elevated mood (mania or hypomania) and deep depression that can significantly disrupt daily functioning.

congenital prothrombin deficiency, a rare autosomal recessive bleeding disorder caused by genetic mutations that result in either reduced levels or dysfunctional prothrombin—manifesting as hypoprothrombinemia (type I) or dysprothrombinemia (type II)—and affecting approximately 1 in 2,000,000 individuals.
psoriatic arthritis, a chronic inflammatory arthritis associated with psoriasis that causes joint pain, stiffness, and swelling.
hypervitaminosis, a condition resulting from abnormally high levels of vitamins in the body that can lead to toxic symptoms and adverse health effects.

renal tubular acidosis, is a disorder in which the kidneys fail to properly excrete acid or reabsorb bicarbonate, leading to a non-anion gap hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis and associated electrolyte and bone complications.

cutaneous neuroendocrine carcinoma, a rare and aggressive skin cancer that typically presents as a single, painless bump on sun-exposed areas and rapidly progresses with a high potential for regional and distant metastases.
malignant mesothelioma (disease), is a rare, aggressive cancer that develops in the mesothelium—the thin lining of the lungs, chest, and abdomen—primarily caused by asbestos exposure.

phosphoribosylpyrophosphate synthetase deficiency, an X-linked disorder caused by missense mutations in the PRPS1 gene that impair purine biosynthesis, resulting in a clinical spectrum from sensorineural hearing loss and peripheral neuropathy to the severe multisystem involvement seen in Arts syndrome.
Felty syndrome, a rare complication of rheumatoid arthritis characterized by an enlarged spleen and low white blood cell count that increases the risk of infections.

capillary leak syndrome, a rare and potentially life-threatening condition characterized by the leakage of plasma, fluid, and proteins from blood vessels into surrounding tissues, which can cause severe hypotension, edema, and other systemic complications.

sudden cardiac arrest, a life-threatening condition in which the heart unexpectedly stops pumping blood effectively—often triggered by coronary artery disease or a heart attack—resulting in immediate loss of consciousness that requires prompt CPR and defibrillation to prevent serious brain damage or death.
cardiac arrest, a sudden and unexpected stoppage of heart function that halts blood flow to vital organs and requires immediate intervention to prevent death.

disease: distal myopathy with anterior tibial onset
description: distal myopathy with anterior tibial onset, a rare genetic neuromuscular disease characterized by progressive muscle weakness beginning in the anterior tibial muscles, later spreading to other limb muscles, elevated serum creatine kinase levels, and absence of dysferlin on muscle biopsy.

testicular cancer, a malignancy originating in the testicles—most often from germ cells in men aged 15 to 44—that typically presents as a lump or swelling in the scrotum and is highly treatable when detected early.

disease: attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, inattentive type
description: attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, inattentive type, is a neurodevelopmental condition marked by persistent difficulties with focus, organization, and task completion without prominent hyperactive or impulsive behaviors.

ATTRV122I amyloidosis, a hereditary transthyretin-related systemic amyloidosis caused by a TTR gene mutation that predominantly leads to myocardial amyloid deposition and restrictive cardiomyopathy with variable clinical presentations and prognosis.
